Sec. 2-291. - Established. There is hereby established the Thomson-McDuffie County Clean Community Commission. (Ord. of 11-7-79, § 1) Sec. 2-292. - Duties. The duties of the clean community commission shall be to promote public interest in the general improvement of the environment of Thomson-McDuffie County, to initiate, plan, direct and coordinate programs for litter control for the Thomson-McDuffie clean community system, and to study, investigate and develop plans for improving the health, sanitation, safety, and cleanliness of the county by beautifying the streets, highways, alleys, river and streambeds, lots, yards, and other similar places in the county; to aid in the prevention of fires, diseases and other casualties by the removal and elimination of trash and other debris from the streets, highways, alleys, lots, yards, plots, and other similar places; to encourage the placing, planting and/or preservation of trees, flowers, plants, shrubbery and other objects or ornamentation in the county; to protect songbirds and other wild fowl; to advise and recommend plans to other agencies of the county for the beautification of the county and otherwise to promote public interest in the general improvement of the environment of Thomson-McDuffie County; provided, however, that nothing in this division shall be construed to abridge or change the powers and duties of other commissions' departments, board, and other like agencies of the county. (Ord. of 11-7-79, § 1) Sec. 2-293. - Powers. In order to perform the duties outlined in section 2-292, the clean community commission shall have the authority to: (1) Adopt bylaws to facilitate the attainment of its purpose and functions; (2) Initiate, plan, direct, and coordinate communitywide efforts to achieve its goals; (3) Solicit and accept donations and appropriations of money, services, products, property and facilities for expenditure and use by the commission for the accomplishment of its objectives; (4) Employ, pay and terminate the employment of such staff as may be required for the fulfillment of commission purposes; and (5) Make recommendations to city and county governing bodies as well as to the private sector regarding measures which it deems necessary to accomplish its objectives. (Ord. of 11-7-79, § 1) Sec. 2-294. - Membership. (a) The clean community commission shall consist of no more than 22 members who shall be residents of Thomson or McDuffie County and who shall serve without remuneration. Members shall be appointed by the mayor and council of the City of Thomson, the board of commissioners of the county, and the Thomson/McDuffie County Chamber of Commerce. (b) In addition to the appointed members of the commission, the mayor of Thomson, the chairman of the county board of commissioners and the president of the Thomson/McDuffie County Chamber of Commerce shall serve as ex-officio members of the commission. (Ord. of 11-7-79, § 1) Sec. 2-295. - Terms of office. The terms of office of the members of the clean community commission shall generally be for two years each. Members whose terms have expired shall continue as members until their successors shall have been appointed. (Ord. of 11-7-79, § 1) Sec. 2-296. - Election of officers. The clean community commission shall elect from its memberships a chairman and such other officers as may be desired. Officers shall be elected on a calendar year basis but may be reelected for succeeding terms. (Ord. of 11-7-79, § 1) Sec. 2-297. - Management of funds. (a) The clean community commission shall have the power to receive and disburse funds within the limitations of appropriations, gifts which have been previously approved jointly by the city and the county, and in connection with projects or undertaking previously approved. Within the same limitations, the commission shall be empowered to contract with any private or public agency to the extent required for its proper operation. The commission shall report to the city and county its acting and doings in connection with each project or undertaking and shall include as part of its report, a statement of its receipts and disbursements, from whatever source and to every object, for the preceding 12 months. Additionally, upon the completion of each project or undertaking, the commission shall make a complete report to the city and county with respect to such project or undertaking, showing the action in connection therewith and any funds received or expended in its behalf. The commission shall keep such records as will enable it to make such reports and accountings, and the records shall be subject to verification and examination by auditors of the city and/or county. (b) Any project or undertaking begun by the commission shall be terminated at any time upon the decision of either the mayor and council of the City of Thomson or the county board of commissioners that the continuance thereof is not in public interest. (Ord. of 11-7-79, § 1) Sec. 2-298. - Compensation. All of the members of the clean community commission shall serve without pay. (Ord. of 11-7-79, § 1) Secs. 2-299—2-320. - Reserved. Sec. 2-321. - Creation. There is hereby created a human relations commission for the City of Thomson and the County of McDuffie to be called Thomson/McDuffie County Human Relations Commission. (Ord. No. 453, § 1, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-322. - Composition. The human relations commission shall be composed of 12 members with equal representation from all ethnic segments of the city and county, 10 of which shall be bona fide adult residents of the city and/or county, and two of which shall be student residents of the city and/or county, with all members appointed by the city council of Thomson and the board of commissioners of McDuffie County, with the advice of the human relations commission. Its membership shall represent a cross section of the community from the following interests or groups: industry, government, health, housing, labor, commerce, agriculture, law enforcement, ministry, etc. The chairman of the commission shall not vote unless it is necessary to break a tie vote. The mayor of the City of Thomson and the chairman of the board of commissioners of McDuffie County or their designees, shall be ex officio nonvoting members of the commission. (Ord. No. 453, § 2, 1-11-90; Res. of 3-1-00, § 2) Sec. 2-323. - Terms of office. Initial appointments to the human relations commission shall be as follows: five members for a period of three years; five members for a period of four years; five members for a period of five years; and five members for a period of six years. Following the expiration of the initial terms of office, all other appointments shall be for a period of four years except in the event of death or resignation of any member. Upon the death or resignation of any member, his successor shall be appointed to serve for the unexpired term for which such member has been appointed; provided, however, the ethnic balance is maintained. All members shall continue in office until their successors shall have been appointed, and there shall be no limit to terms of office. Any student member shall serve a term to expire upon graduation from high school. (Ord. No. 453, § 3, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-324. - Officers and their terms of office. The human relations commission shall elect a chairman and such other officers as it deems necessary from its members. Such officers shall serve in their respective offices for a term of one year or until their successors shall be appointed. They may be reelected. (Ord. No. 453, § 4, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-325. - Compensation. All members of the human relations commission shall serve without compensation. (Ord. No. 453, § 5, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-326. - Executive directors and staff. The appointment of the executive directors of the human relations commission shall be made by the board of commissioners of McDuffie County and the city [council] of Thomson, with the advice of the human relations commission. The executive directors shall be persons with training and experience in intergroup and interracial relations. Initially this position shall be in total part-time, 20 hours per week until a greater time commitment is warranted. He shall coordinate the activities of the commission and staff. He may, with the approval of the commission and within the budget of the commission, employ such staff as needed. The compensation, if any, of the executive directors and other staff shall be as provided in the budget approved by the city council of Thomson and the county board of commissioners. Following the initial appointment of the executive directors, the executive directors shall serve at the pleasure of the city council of Thomson and board of commissioners of McDuffie County; provided, however, that the termination of the executive directors or the employment of new executive directors shall receive the concurrence of the city council and the county commissioners. (Ord. No. 453, § 6, 1-11-90; Res. of 3-1-00, § 3) Sec. 2-327. - Office space and facilities. The city council and the board of commissioners are authorized to secure adequate office space and facilities for the human relations commission. (Ord. No. 453, § 7, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-328. - Budget and finance. The human relations commission shall annually adopt the budget to be submitted for approval to the city council and the board of commissioners. The commission shall be authorized to contract with the state and federal agencies, but such contracts must first be approved by the city council and county commission. All expenditures of the commission shall be limited to those as specified by the budget. (Ord. No. 453, § 8, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-329. - Inspection and audit of financial records. The financial records of the human relations commission shall be audited annually by a qualified external auditor. Such audit, when completed, shall be submitted to the commission for approval, and a copy shall be provided to the internal auditor of the city council and the board of commissioners. All financial records of the commission shall be open for inspection by the county grand jury. (Ord. No. 453, § 9, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-330. - Meetings. The human relations commission shall set forth the time, place, and frequency of its meetings to effectuate the purpose of this division, and such meetings shall be open to the public. The commission reserves the right to deliberation in closed session, consistent with state law. (Ord. No. 453, § 10, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-331. - Quorum. Seven members of the human relations commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. (Ord. No. 453, § 11, 1-11-90; Res. of 3-1-00, § 4) Sec. 2-332. - Rules and bylaws. The human relations commission shall adopt such rules as it deems expedient for the conduct of its business. (Ord. No. 453, § 12, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-333. - Reports. The human relations commission shall report in writing its activities to the city council and the county commission annually and make such other reports from time to time, or after the completion of any hearing as it may determine necessary, setting forth the facts found by it and its recommendations in the furtherance of its objectives. (Ord. No. 453, § 13, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-334. - Duties and powers. It shall be the duty of the human relations commission to: (1) Seek fair and equal treatment under the law for all citizens. (2) Attempt to act as conciliator in controversies involving human relations. (3) Promote mutual understanding, tolerance, and respect among all economic, racial, religious and nationality groups and work to discourage and prevent discriminatory practices against any such groups. (4) Study the problems of group relationships and promote amiable relations among racial and cultural groups and strive to eliminate whatever sources of interracial friction may exist. (5) Take appropriate steps by conference and education to deal with conditions that strain relationships. (6) Aid in the coordination of the activities of private organizations concerned with these relationships. (7) Make such investigations, studies, and surveys, and conduct such public hearings and make such recommendations to the city council and the county commission as in its judgment will effectuate the policy of this division and as are necessary for the performance of its duties. (8) Maintain contacts with groups concerned with interracial and intercultural understanding. (9) Serve as a source of accurate and reliable data on the problems in the fields mentioned in this section. (10) Work to remove inequalities, if any, which pertain to minority groups' status, such as problems of housing, recreation, education, law enforcement, employment, vocational guidance and related matters. (11) Investigate and study complaints, problems and specific situations arising between groups or individuals which result or may result in tensions, discrimination or prejudice in the county on account of race, color, religion, national origin, handicap or age. (12) Receive and investigate complaints alleging discrimination in employment and public accommodations because of race, religion, color, sex, national origin, handicap or age. (13) Endeavor by education to induce public and private employers, labor and professional organizations and employment agencies to institute nondiscriminatory practices in employment, promotion, wages, working conditions, layoffs, and job opportunities. (14) Endeavor by education to engender respect for law and order and lawful authority and promote amenability to law enforcement; distinguish between peaceful dissent and illegal disorder and violence; and promote a sense of individual responsibility and respect for each other without regard to race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap, or age. (15) Endeavor by education to increase racial pride without resentment toward other races, and to point out that the manifestations of racial hatred and acts of lawlessness directed toward other races generate and intensify counteracting racial prejudice and retaliatory racial discrimination. (16) Disseminate information that no group or individual is entitled to special privileges, treatment, protection, or immunity by reason of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, social, or economic condition, handicap, or age, but that all have equal responsibility to strive for self-advancement and improvement, civic good, and community welfare and best interests. (17) Secure the furnishings of equal services to all residents, and where the need is greater in meeting that need with additional services. (18) Train city and county employees to use methods of dealing with intergroup relations which develop respect for equal rights and which result in equal treatment without regard to race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age or handicap. (19) Assist in improving the equality of opportunity for employment and advancement in the city and county government. (20) Adopt, promulgate, amend, and rescind suitable rules and procedures to carry out the provisions of this division. (21) Recommend to the city council and the county commission such additional ordinances as will aid in carrying out the purpose of this division. (22) Advise, consult with, and make recommendations to the city council and the county commission, agencies and officials, for the betterment of intergroup relationships and ways and means of discouraging and combatting prejudice, intolerance and bigotry in all groups and in their relations with one another. (23) Discover practices and policies calculated to create conflicts, tensions, unfair or unjust discrimination which would be deemed detrimental to the community's best interests and recommend ways and means for their elimination. (24) Inform and warn the public of false and sinister propaganda subversive to public interest and search out and reveal sources of inflammatory, lewd, vulgar and profane racial propaganda. (Ord. No. 453, § 14, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-335. - Equal employment practices. The human relations commission desires to assist both employers and employees in resolving any questions of equal employment, based on EEOC guidelines, laws of the state and the United States of America. (Ord. No. 453, § 15, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-336. - Procedures for redress of practices contrary to this division. (a) Any person alleging a practice contrary to this division must file a written complaint with the human relations commission or its designated representative no later than 180 days after the alleged practice occurred. (b) Upon receipt of a complaint, the commission shall be certain that all avenues of reconciliation have been expired at the source of the conflict. If warranted, it shall serve a copy of the complaint on the respondent within ten days of receipt thereof and shall conduct an investigation of the complaint. (c) If the commission determines after such investigation that there is reasonable cause to believe the charge is true, the commission shall endeavor to eliminate any such alleged practice by informal and voluntary methods of conference, conciliation, and persuasion. During such informal endeavors, the commission may seek from the respondent such relief as may be appropriate. (d) All investigations, conferences, and negotiations for conciliation pursuant to this division shall be confidential. Further, at no time shall the results of any conciliation be made public without the expressed written consent of the parties involved. (e) If within ten days after the commission has determined that conciliation efforts have failed, it shall so notify the parties in writing, and the respondent may request a hearing before the commission within ten days of the receipt of such notice. (f) If the commission determines that the complaint as alleged is not true, it shall dismiss the complaint and notify the parties in writing of such determination. Within ten days of receipt of such notice of dismissal, the complainant may request a hearing from the commission. A request for a hearing shall be granted expeditiously. No hearing may be had from a finding and determination of a lack of jurisdiction. At such hearing, the commission may affirm or set aside its findings as set forth in subsection (c) of this section, in whole or in part. (g) If the commission determines after a hearing that any respondent has committed an unlawful act prohibited by this division, and the respondent refuses to comply with an order of the commission within 60 days after notification of such final disposition, or if the respondent fails to request a hearing before the commission within ten days after receipt of notice of failure of conciliation, the commission may refer the complainant to EEOC or other agency for appropriate legal action. (Ord. No. 453, § 16, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-337. - Religious organizations' hiring practices exempted. This division shall not apply to religious corporations, religious associations, religious educational institutions, or religious societies with respect to the employment of individuals of a particular religion to perform work connected with the carrying on by such corporations, associations, educational institutions or societies of its activities. (Ord. No. 453, § 17, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-338. - Cooperation of ethnic, racial, religious and community groups sought. The human relations commission shall invite and enlist the cooperation of all ethnic, racial, and religious groups, and community organizations in carrying on its work and act as a coordinating agency among them and such other groups in the establishment and maintenance of education programs with a view to bringing about better intergroup and racial relationships necessary or desirable to carry out specific programs designed to lessen the tensions or improve understanding. The commission shall also cooperate with the mayor, city council, all other city agencies, the board chairman, county commission, all other county agencies, all state and federal agencies, citizens, citizens' organizations, the board of education, parochial and private schools in formulating and developing courses in education to stimulate the interest of the entire population in the improvement of services wherever such cooperation is appropriate in effectuating the purposes of this division and in accomplishing the objectives of the commission to promote better human relations. (Ord. No. 453, § 18, 1-11-90) Sec. 2-339. - Legal services. Legal representation, advice and review of contracts and other records shall be provided by the city and the county attorneys. Obtaining legal representation other than from the city or county attorney shall require the written approval of the city council and board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 453, § 19, 1-11-90) Secs. 2-340—2-360. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[10]
Footnotes: --- (10) --- State Law reference— Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1; Georgia Development Authority Act, O.C.G.A. § 50-10-1 et seq.
Sec. 2-361. - Declaration of necessity and purpose of division. The county board of commissioners has determined and declared a pressing, existing and future need for a development authority, as more fully described and defined in the development authorities law, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq., to function in the county for the purpose of developing and promoting for the public good and general welfare trade, commerce, industry and employment opportunities in the county, thereby promoting the general welfare of its citizenry. (Res. of 1-17-70(2)) Sec. 2-362. - Creation. There is hereby activated in the county the public body corporate and politic known as the Development Authority of McDuffie County which was created upon the adoption and approval of the development authorities law, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq. (Res. of 1-17-70(2)) Sec. 2-363. - Initial appointment and subsequent election of directors. Commencing with the date of adoption of the resolution from which this division is derived by the county board of commissioners, each of the persons named as initial directors of the development authority shall serve in such capacity for the number of designated years, and, if at the end of any term of office of any director a successor thereto shall not have been elected, then the director whose term of office shall have expired shall continue to hold office until his successor shall be so elected. (Res. of 1-17-70(2)) Sec. 2-364. - Duties and powers in accord with state law. (a) The board of directors of the development authority elected pursuant to section 2-363 shall organize itself, carry out its duties and responsibilities and exercise its powers and prerogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of the development authorities law as it now exists and as it might hereafter be amended or modified. (b) The clerk of the county board of commissioners shall furnish immediately to the secretary of state of the State of Georgia a certified copy of this division in compliance with the mandate set forth in O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq. (Res. of 1-17-70(2)) Sec. 2-365. - Public hearings. In connection with any issue of obligation by the development authority, the development authority is authorized and directed to conduct on behalf of the county any public hearing required by section 103(k)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954, as amended, or any successor or similar provision now or hereafter in effect. (Res. of 10-10-83) Secs. 2-366—2-370. - Reserved. DIVISION 6. - DRUG ABUSE TREATMENT AND EDUCATION FUND BOARD
Sec. 2-371. - Creation. There is hereby created the county drug abuse treatment and education fund board. This board is created to determine appropriate uses of the funds deposited in the county drug abuse treatment and education fund in the future and to suggest uses of the funds presently in the fund for approval by the county and to provide and assure appropriate supervision and management of these funds. (Res. of 8-16-05, § 1) Sec. 2-372. - Supervision and management of funds. The county drug abuse and education fund board shall provide appropriate supervision and management of the funds so under their care and control and it shall determine appropriate drug abuse treatment and education programs for spending these funds. The board shall meet quarterly to discuss how funds are to be expended and to insure the appropriate supervision and management of the funds. The board shall report at least annually to the board of commissioners how the funds were used to insure compliance with the Georgia Code. (Res. of 8-16-05, § 2) Sec. 2-373. - Compositon of board. (a) The composition of the county drug abuse treatment and education fund board shall be individuals selected by the Board of Commissioners of McDuffie County from the following entities: (1) Class I. a. Law enforcement: 1. Sheriff's department; 2. Thomson City Police. b. Judicial system: 1. Superior court clerk; 2. Judge. c. District attorney's office. d. Public defender's office. (2) Class II. a. State board of pardons and parole. b. State probation office. c. CSRA probation services. d. City government. 1. Thomson; 2. Dearing. (3) Class III. a. County government; b. McDuffie County Board of Education; c. Department of family and children's services; d. McDuffie County Community Mental Health; e. Department of juvenile justice. (b) This board shall be created in three classes with staggered three-year terms. Class I shall be appointed for a term ending December 31, 2005. Class II directors shall be appointed for a term ending December 31, 2006, and the Class III directors shall be appointed for a term ending on December 31, 2007. At the expiration of each class's initial term, they shall thereafter be appointed by the Board of Commissioners of McDuffie County for three-year terms. (Res. of 8-16-05, § 3) Sec. 2-374. - Approval of board of commissioners required to spend existing funds. There are presently funds in the county drug abuse and treatment education fund from previous years that are to be used for special purposes in the future. The county drug abuse and treatment education fund board may spend these preexisting funds for special educational activities and drug abuse treatment programs only with the prior approval of the Board of Commissioners of McDuffie County. (Res. of 8-16-05, § 4) Secs. 2-375—2-385. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - FINANCE[11] Footnotes: --- (11) --- State Law reference— Power of expenditure, Ga. Const., art. 9, sec. 4, par. 2; discretion of governing body as to management and disposition of property, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-2; multiyear lease, purchase or lease purchase contracts, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-13; budgets and audits, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-1 et seq.; accounting for public funds, O.C.G.A. § 45-8-1 et seq.; local political subdivision purchases, O.C.G.A. § 50-5-100 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-386—2-400. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS PROGRAM
Sec. 2-401. - Process adopted for preparation and review of program. The following process is hereby adopted for the preparation and review of a capital improvements program and capital budget for the county: (1) The commission shall obtain annually from all officers, departments, boards, and commissions, and other agencies requesting funds from the county for capital improvements, such information as may be necessary in order to enable the board of commissioners to prepare a capital improvements program. (2) The board of commissioners shall have the power to accept, with or without amendment, or reject the proposed program and the proposed means of financing. The board of commissioners shall not authorize budgets for the construction or acquisition of any building, structure, work or improvement, unless the appropriation of such project is included in its capital budget, except to meet a public emergency threatening the lives, health, or property of inhabitants, when so determined by the board of commissioners. (3) Only those projects which are proved to have the highest priority in meeting the essential needs of the county and have a strong indication that funding will be forthcoming in the ensuing fiscal year should be included in the capital budget portion of the capital improvements program. (4) The department heads may submit amendments to the capital budget at any time during the year. The amendments shall become effective when approved by the board of commissioners. (5) The board of commissioners may, if they deem it advisable, appoint a capital improvements program and capital advisory committee which shall have the responsibility for making recommendations to the board of commissioners on capital projects essential to the overall development of the county. (Res. of 11-19-91, §§ 1—5) Secs. 2-402—2-430. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PURCHASING[12]
Footnotes: --- (12) --- State Law reference— Board of commissioners authority to control property of the county, O.C.G.A. § 36-5-22.1; county property generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-9-1 et seq.
Sec. 2-431. - Purpose and policy of division. It is expressly declared to be the purpose and policy of this division to ensure the procurement for the county the highest quality in goods, materials, supplies, equipment, or other property at the least expense to the county, to discourage uniform bidding and endeavor to obtain as full and open competition as possible on all purchases and sales. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-103) Sec. 2-432. - Authority of division. (a) Except as provided in this division, it shall be unlawful for any county officer or employee to order the purchase of any goods, materials, supplies, equipment, or other property or make any contract within the purview of this division other than as provided in this division. Any purchase order or contract made contrary to the provisions of this division shall not be approved by the county commissioners, and the county shall not be bound thereby. (b) It is the responsibility of each department supervisor to ensure that each of his subordinates is instructed in the use of these purchasing procedures. Any purchase not made in accordance with these procedures automatically becomes the direct, personal obligation of the individual making such purchase. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-102) Sec. 2-433. - Purchase orders. No officer or employee of the county shall request any merchant, dealer, or other vendor to deliver goods to the county except on an official McDuffie County purchase order. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-104; Mo. of 1-7-04(1)) Sec. 2-434. - Vendors' catalog file. The board of commissioners shall maintain a file of all qualified vendors desiring to do business with the county. Such file shall be maintained according to materials and shall contain a description of the vendors' commodities. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-105) Sec. 2-435. - Purchases under $1,000.00. The board of commissioners, the county manager, and boards or commissions established under the board of commissioners is hereby authorized to purchase any goods, materials, supplies, equipment, parts, or any other property of any nature, used by the county in any of its governmental affairs, from any vendor listed in the county vendors catalog file, without bid and legal advertisement, when the cost of same does not exceed $1,000.00. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-106, Mo. of 1-7-04(1); Ord. of 4-1-15(1)) Sec. 2-436. - Purchases between $1,000.00 and $5,000.00. (a) The board of commissioners, the county manager, and boards or commissions established under the board of commissioners after approval by the board of commissioners, is hereby authorized to purchase any goods, materials, supplies, equipment, parts, or any other property of any nature, used by the county in any of its governmental affairs, without bid and legal advertisement, by obtaining not less than three written quotations, if available, by either direct mail requests or telephone to vendors from the county vendors catalog file and a record of the quotations maintained which shall be available for public inspection, when the cost of such purchase is between $1,000.00 and $5,000.00. (b) If capital items are specifically included in the adopted county budget, the county manager or any board or commission established under the board of commissioners is hereby authorized to purchase any such items without bid and legal advertisement by obtaining not less than three written quotations, if available, by either direct mail or telephone requests to vendors from the county vendors catalog file and a record of the quotations maintained which shall be available for public inspection when the cost of such purchase does not exceed $5,000.00. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-107; Mo. of 1-7-04(1); Ord. of 4-1-15(1)) Sec. 2-437. - Purchases over $5,000.00. (a) With the exceptions provided in this division, the board of commissioners and boards and commissions established under the board of commissioners shall in all other instances before purchasing any such goods, materials, supplies, equipment, parts, or any other property of any nature, to be used by the county, or enter into any lease of equipment to be used by the county, advertise for bids two times in the county legal gazette. (b) The newspaper notice required in subsection (a) of this section shall include a general description of the articles to be purchased, shall state where bid blanks and specifications may be secured, and shall state the time and place for opening bids. (c) Notwithstanding any provision of this section, bids for new motor vehicles and new heavy equipment may be solicited without any advertising in the local county legal gazette. (d) Notwithstanding any provision of this section, bids on any purchase over $5,000.00 may be authorized without any requirement of advertising in the local county legal gazette, if approved by a majority vote of the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-108; Ord. of 9-17-02; Ord. of 4-1-15(1)) Sec. 2-438. - Bids based on written specifications. All quotations and bids referred to in sections 2-436 and 2-437 shall be based upon written specifications prepared by the appropriate county official, which shall be available during normal office hours at the county commission offices. All specifications shall be definite and certain and shall permit free and open competition. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-114) Sec. 2-439. - Bid opening procedures. (a) Bids shall be submitted sealed to the board of commissioners or the respective board or commission established under the board of commissioners and shall be identified as bids on the envelope. (b) Bids shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the public notices. (c) A tabulation of all bids received shall be available for public inspection in the commission's office. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-109; Ord. of 4-1-15(1)) Sec. 2-440. - Rejection of bids. The board of commissioners or boards or commissions established under the board of commissioners shall have the authority to reject all bids or quotations, parts of all bids or quotations, or all bids or quotations for any one or more supplies or contractual services included in the proposed contract, when the public interest will be served thereby. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-110; Ord. of 4-1-15(1)) Sec. 2-441. - Bidders in default to county. The county commission or boards or commissions established under the board of commissioners shall not accept the bid of a contractor who is in default on the payment of taxes, licenses, or other monies due the county. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-111; Ord. of 4-1-15(1)) Sec. 2-442. - Lowest responsible bidder. (a) Contracts shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder. In determining the lowest responsible bidder, in addition to price, the county commission or boards or commissions established under the board of commissioners shall consider: (1) The ability, capacity, and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required. (2) Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference. (3) The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience, and efficiency of the bidder. (4) The quality of performance of previous contracts or services. (5) The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to the contract or service. (6) The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service. (7) The quality, availability, and adaptability of the supplies, or contractual services to the particular use required. (8) The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract. (9) The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid. (b) When the award is not given to the lowest bidder, a full and complete statement of the reasons for placing the order elsewhere shall be prepared by the county commission or boards or commissions established under the board of commissioners and filed with the other documents relating to the transaction. (c) In the implementation of these procedures, the county commission shall in no way discriminate against any person by reason of race, color, creed, nationality, or religion. Minority businesses shall be encouraged to participate in the bidding and purchasing procedures for the county to the fullest extent possible. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-112; Ord. of 4-1-15(1)) Sec. 2-443. - Bids to be filed and subject to inspection. All bids for goods or materials provided for in this division of any kind or character purchased by the county shall be kept on file in the county commission offices. After an award has been made, the bids shall be subject to inspection at any time by any citizen of the county. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-113) Sec. 2-444. - Used equipment. (a) Notwithstanding anything in this division to the contrary, the board of commissioners is authorized to purchase used equipment for the operation of its governmental affairs based upon a written appraisal obtained by the county for the subject equipment. Such written appraisal, together with the acceptance and approval, shall be entered upon the regular minutes of the board of commissioners at the time the board considers the purchase of any used equipment. Furthermore, no such purchase shall be consummated without an express agreement that the county shall be allowed to return the equipment at any time within 30 days of the consummation of the sale, cancel the sale, and receive a full refund, normal wear and tear excepted, of the purchase price. (b) (1) Not withstanding the above for any used equipment less than $49,500.00 in value, the requirement of appraisal may be waived by majority vote of the board of commissioners as long as the board is provided the price of a similar new piece of equipment and provided the equipment is inspected by an appropriate county employee prior to the purchase. (2) Notwithstanding the above for any used equipment less than $49,500.00 in value, the requirement of the 30 day right to cancel sale and receive full refund maybe waived by the majority vote of the board of commissioners provided the equipment is inspected by an appropriate county employee prior to the purchase. (Ord. of 11-6-91, § 1-114.1; Ord. of 2-20-03; Ord. of 8-4-04) Sec. 2-445. - Local vendors. In the purchase of all goods, materials, supplies, equipment, parts, or any other property of any nature, used by the county in any of its governmental affairs, all possible efforts shall be made to ensure that local vendors have ample opportunity to bid on such purchases. Nothing contained in this section, however, shall prohibit the board of commissioners or boards or commissions established under the board of commissioners from purchasing from nonresident vendors if it is in the best interest of the county, or from taking advantage of any cooperative purchasing plans available through any state governmental agency or governmental association. The board of commissioners shall in all instances exercise its most prudent judgment for the best interest of the county as a whole. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-115; Ord. of 4-1-15(1)) Sec. 2-446. - Emergency purchases. If the board of commissioners determines at an open meeting of which minutes are recorded, that an emergency exists, and there is an immediate need for goods, materials, supplies, equipment, parts, or any other property of any nature, used by the county in any of its governmental affairs, to relieve the emergency, the board of commissioners shall be allowed to approve purchases without bids if the board has determined that an emergency exists. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-116; Ord. of 9-17-02) Sec. 2-447. - No bids or quotations received. If the board of commissioners or boards or commissions established under the board of commissioners receives no bids or quotations, as the case may be, the board of commissioners or respective board or commission established under the board of commissioners is hereby authorized to negotiate for the purchase of the goods, materials, supplies, equipment, parts, or any other property of any nature, needed for the operation of its governmental affairs; provided, however, that any such negotiated bid shall be read one time in a commission meeting and formally approved at a subsequent commission meeting. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-117; Ord. of 9-17-02; Ord. of 4-1-15(1)) Sec. 2-448. - Prohibition of interest by board. (a) Any purchase order or contract within the purview of this division in which any member of the board of commissioners, or any member of a board or commission established under the board of commissioners for which the specific purchase or contract shall be authorized, any officer or employee of the county, or any family member of either residing in the same household is financially interested, directly or indirectly, shall be void, except that before the execution of the purchase order or contract, the board of commissioners shall have the authority to waive compliance with this section when it finds such action to be in the best interest of the county. (b) All members of the board of commissioners, members of boards or commissions established under the board of commissioners, and every officer and employee of the county are expressly prohibited from accepting, directly or indirectly, from any person to which any purchase order or contract is or might be awarded, any rebate, gift, money, or anything of value whatsoever, except where given for the use and benefit of the county. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-118; Ord. of 4-1-15(1)) Sec. 2-449. - Performance bonds. The county commission shall have the authority to require a performance bond before entering a contract, in such amount as it shall find reasonably necessary to protect the best interests of the county. (Ord. of 3-7-90, § 1-119) Secs. 2-450—2-475. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - CODE AND ORDINANCE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER[13]
Footnotes: --- (13) --- Cross reference— Personnel, ch. 58.
Sec. 2-476. - Creation. There is hereby created the position of code and ordinance enforcement officer for the county. (Ord. of 5-6-92(3)) Sec. 2-477. - Duties, responsibilities and powers. (a) The duties and responsibilities of the enforcement officer shall be to enforce any and all codes and ordinances heretofore or hereafter enacted by the county board of commissioners, to issue citations for violations of any codes or ordinances and to prosecute such violations with or without a prosecuting attorney. In all instances where such officer desires the assistance of a prosecuting attorney, the county attorney shall serve in that capacity. Notwithstanding anything contained in this section, the county code and ordinance enforcement officer shall have no arrest powers. If arrest becomes necessary, such officer shall immediately turn the matter over to the county sheriff's department. (b) Each citation issued by the county code and ordinance enforcement officer shall state the time and place at which the accused is to appear for trial, shall identify the offense with which the accused is charged, shall have an identifying number by which it shall be filed with the court, shall indicate the identity of the accused and the date of service, and shall be signed by the county code and ordinance enforcement officer. The prosecution for violations of county codes and ordinances upon the citation issued by the enforcement officer shall be commenced by the completion, signing, and service of a citation by the county code and enforcement officer. The original of the citation shall be personally served upon the accused, and a copy shall promptly be filed with the magistrate court, who shall try all violations. (c) Any defendant who fails to appear for trial shall be arrested thereafter on the warrant of the magistrate and required to post a bond for his future appearance. (d) Execution may issue immediately upon any fine imposed by the magistrate court and not immediately paid. The county sheriff shall receive and house all persons sentenced to confinement for contempt or arrested or sentenced to confinement for violation of county codes or ordinances. (e) Review of convictions shall be by certiorari to the county superior court. (Ord. of 5-6-92(3))

div.head: Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; businesses, ch. 18; health and sanitation, ch. 38; offenses, ch. 50; alcoholic beverages in parks, § 54-38; taxation, ch. 78. State Law reference— Use of proceeds of alcoholic beverage tax for prevention, education and treatment, Ga. Const. art. 3, sec. 9, par. 6(e); Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41; furnishing alcoholic beverages to persons under 21 years of age, jurisdiction of municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-10; treatment of alcoholics and intoxicated persons, O.C.G.A. § 37-8-1 et seq.; driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-391.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, from whatever source or by whatever process produced. Alcoholic beverage means and includes all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverage, wine or fortified wine. Beer or malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by any fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops, or any other similar product, or any combination of such products in water containing not more than six percent alcohol by volume, and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, small beer, and strong beer. The term "malt beverage" does not include sake, known as Japanese rice wine. Distilled spirits or spirituous liquor means any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation or containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume, including, but not limited to, all fortified wines. Fortified wine means any alcoholic beverage containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries, or grapes, either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. Fortified wine includes, but is not limited to, brandy. Hotel means any building or other structure providing sleeping accommodations for hire to the general public, either transient, permanent, or residential. Such hotels shall maintain a minimum of 25 rooms available for hire. Motels meeting the qualifications set out in this section for hotels shall be classified in the same category as hotels. Hotels shall have the privilege of granting franchises for the operation of any licensed establishment, and the holder of such franchise shall be included in the definition of a hotel pursuant to this section. Licensee means the individual to whom a license is issued and, in the case of a partnership or corporation, all partners, officers, and directors of the partnership or corporation. Liter means metric measurement currently used by the United States. Lounge means a separate room, with a seating capacity for a minimum of 50 people, connected with or a part of a restaurant or located in hotels, all booths, stools, and tables being unobstructed and open to view. A lounge which is operated on a different floor in the premises, or in a separate building, or is not connected to or part of a restaurant shall be considered a separate establishment and shall be separately licensed. Manufacturer means any maker, producer, or bottler of an alcoholic beverage. Manufacturer also means: (1) In the case of distilled spirits, any person engaged in distilling, rectifying, or blending any distilled spirits. (2) In the case of malt beverages, any brewer. (3) In the case of wine, any vintner. Nightclub means an establishment having the seating capacity of at least 50 persons, with all booths and tables being unobstructed and open to view, and providing a band and/or other professional entertainment a minimum of 20 days per month, each and every month, with the exception of holidays, vacations, and periods of redecorating. All such nightclubs shall maintain an adequate kitchen with a sufficient number of servants and employees for cooking, preparing and serving food and meals for their patrons, provided that nightclubs located in hotels having dining room and kitchen facilities may be excluded from maintaining a kitchen in connection with such nightclub. The principal business of such nightclubs shall be entertainment, and the serving of food and of alcoholic beverages shall be only incidental thereto. Package means a bottle, can, keg, barrel, or other original consumer container. Private club means an association, partnership, or corporation organized and existing under the laws of the state, actively in operation within the county at least one year immediately prior to the application for a license pursuant to this chapter; having at least 75 members regularly paying monthly, quarterly, or semiannual dues; organized and operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation, and other nonprofitable purposes, no part of the net earning of which inures to the benefit of any shareholder or member; and owning, hiring, or leasing a building or space therein for the reasonable use of its members; provided, that no member or officer, agent or employee of the club is paid, directly or indirectly receives, in the form of salary or other compensation, any profits of the sale of alcoholic beverages to the club or its members or guests beyond the amount of such as may be fixed by its members at any annual meeting or by its governing board out of the general revenue of the club. Restaurant means any public place selling prepared food for consumption by the public on the premises with a full service kitchen. A full service kitchen will consist of a three-compartment pot sink, a stove or grill permanently installed, and refrigerator all of which must be approved by the health and fire departments. Such restaurant will be prepared to serve food every hour it is open and where these establishments can seat 50 or more persons. At least two meals per day shall be served at least six days a week, with the exception of holidays, vacations, and periods of redecorating; and the serving of such meals shall be the principal business conducted, with the serving of alcoholic beverages to be consumed on the premises as only incidental thereto. Retailer, retail dealer, retail licensee, or retail outlet means any person or other legal entity selling alcoholic beverages, either in unbroken packages or for consumption on the premises, at retail only to consumers and not for resale. Tavern means any establishment or room, with a seating capacity for less than 50 people, serving only the alcoholic beverages for which it is licensed on the premises. Wholesaler or wholesaler dealer means any person who sells alcoholic beverages to other wholesale dealers, to retail dealers, or to retail consumption dealers. Wine means any alcoholic beverage containing not more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries, or grapes, either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. Wine includes, but is not limited to, all sparkling wines, rectified wines, and like products. The term "wine" does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. A liquid shall first be deemed to be a wine at that point in the manufacturing process when it conforms to the definition of wine contained in this section. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-102; Mo. of 12-3-97, § 2) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 6-2. - Penalties for violation of chapter. Any person who violates any provision of this chapter may, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-13. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-136) Sec. 6-3. - Distance requirements for sale. (a) No person, knowingly or intentionally, may sell or offer to sell any alcoholic beverage in or within 100 yards of a church or within 200 yards of any school building. (b) The school building referred to in this section shall apply only to state, county, city or church school buildings and to such buildings at such other schools in which are taught subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of this state. The term "school building" includes only those structures in which instruction is offered. (c) The term "church building" as used in this section shall mean the main structure used by any religious organization for purposes of worship. (d) For the purposes of this section, distance shall be measured in a straight line from the main entrance of the school or church building in question to the main entrance of the establishment for the sale of alcoholic beverages in question. (e) No location which is licensed to sell alcoholic beverages on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall be denied continued operation under an existing license, or denied any renewal of such license, nor shall any new owner of such location be denied a new license based upon the measurements set forth in this section. (f) As to any location licensed in the future, if the distance requirements in this section are met at the time of issuance of any license, the subsequent opening and operation of a church or school within the distance prohibited in this section shall not prevent the continuance of an existing license or the renewal thereof or the issuance of a new license to any subsequent owner of such property. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-110) Sec. 6-4. - Advertising sale. (a) No outdoor advertising or signs with respect to the promotion of the sale of alcoholic beverages or the prices of such beverages shall be permitted on the exterior of any retail package outlet, consumption on the premises dealer, or in the windows of any such establishment that may be viewed from outside. (b) A licensed retailer may display at his place of business such signs as are permitted by O.C.G.A. § 3-4-3 and the state alcoholic beverage laws, rules and regulations as they may from time to time be amended. (c) Advertising of alcoholic beverages by flyer or coupon by properly licensed consumption on the premises establishments advertising special days, nights, or events is allowed; provided, however, the establishment or group advertising the event and hosting the advertised event shall retrieve all flyers and/or coupons within seven days of being posted and no such flyers or coupons shall be posted or attached to any public property. (d) Retail package licensees shall indicate plainly by tags or labels on the bottles or containers or on the shelf immediately below where the containers are placed, the price of an alcoholic beverage exposed or offered for sale. No other sign may be exposed prominently within or without the retail establishment showing prices or indicating alcoholic beverages are for sale on the premises. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-116; Ord. of 3-5-14, pt. I, § 6-2) Sec. 6-5. - Audits of sales. If the board of commissioners deems it necessary to conduct an audit of the records and books of the licensee, the board of commissioners shall so notify the licensee of the date, time, and place of the audit. The board of commissioners may designate the county's auditor or other designated person to perform any audit authorized in this chapter. Licensees shall cooperate with the audit or forfeit any license issued pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-117) Sec. 6-6. - Collection of sums due. If any person shall fail to pay any sum due under this chapter, the board of commissioners shall issue an execution against the person so delinquent, and his property, for the amount of the delinquent fee or tax. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-118) Sec. 6-7. - Retailer to purchase from licensed wholesaler only. (a) No retailer shall purchase alcoholic beverages from any person other than a wholesaler licensed under this chapter. No wholesaler shall sell any alcoholic beverage to anyone other than a retailer licensed under this chapter; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the purchase by one retailer of another retailer's entire stock in a bona fide purchase of an ongoing business. (b) The board of commissioners may request, from time to time, information concerning purchases and sales of alcoholic beverages from retailers and wholesalers. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-119) Sec. 6-8. - Retail consumption dealers to store inventory only on premises. No retail consumption dealer licensed pursuant to this chapter shall keep any beer or wine or other alcoholic beverages at any place except the licensed place of business. No retail consumption dealer shall be permitted to enter into any type of arrangement whereby distilled spirits ordered by a licensee are stored by a licensed wholesaler. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-120) Sec. 6-9. - Licensees to maintain a copy of this chapter; employees to be familiar with terms; licensee responsible for violations. Each licensed alcoholic beverage dealer under this chapter shall keep a copy of this chapter in the licensed premises and shall instruct any person working there with respect to the terms hereof. Each licensee, the licensee's agents, and employees selling alcoholic beverages shall at all times be familiar with the terms hereof. The licensee shall be responsible for any acts of agents or employees which are in violation of this chapter, or of the laws of the state, or the rules and regulations of the state revenue commissioner. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-121) Sec. 6-10. - Employment of underage persons prohibited; exceptions. (a) No persons shall allow or require a person in his employment under 18 years of age to dispense, serve, sell, or take orders for any alcoholic beverage. (b) The provisions of this section shall not prohibit persons under 18 years of age who are employed in supermarkets, convenience stores, breweries, or drugstores from selling or handling alcoholic beverages which are sold for consumption off the premises. (c) It is unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years of age to work as an entertainer in any establishment licensed pursuant to this chapter without written consent from the parents or guardian. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-122) Sec. 6-11. - Failure to require and properly check identification of buyers. It shall be a violation not to require and properly check identification to ensure that an underage person is not sold, served, or in possession of alcoholic beverages while in a licensed establishment. Identification in this section shall mean any document issued by a governmental agency containing a description of the person, such person's photograph and giving such person's date of birth and shall include, without being limited to, a passport, military ID card, driver's license or state department of public safety ID card. The penalty for violation of this section shall be as set out in section 6-12(c). (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-123; Mo. of 12-3-97, § 3) Sec. 6-12. - Furnishing in violation of state law. (a) No licensee or employee of a licensee authorizing the sale of alcoholic beverages shall do any of the following upon the licensed premises: (1) Knowingly sell alcoholic beverages to an underage person, presently under 21 years of age, so as to constitute a violation of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23, as presently written or as such section may hereafter be amended from time to time. (2) Knowingly sell or offer to sell any alcoholic beverages to any person who is noticeably intoxicated, who is of unsound mind, or who is a habitual drunkard whose intemperate habits are known to the licensee or his employees. (3) Sell alcoholic beverages upon the licensed premises or permit alcoholic beverages to be consumed thereon, on any day or at any time when the sale or consumption is prohibited by law. (b) No licensee who holds a license to sell alcoholic beverages by the drink shall allow any person under the age of 21 years, to be in, frequent, or loiter about the licensed premises of the establishment, unless such minors are accompanied by a parent, legal guardian, or custodian. No person under the age of 21 years shall be in, frequent, or loiter about the licensed premises of an establishment holding a license to sell alcoholic beverages by the drink; provided, however, persons under 21 years of age shall be permitted in restaurants or private clubs without being accompanied by a parent, legal guardian, or custodian; and provided further that this section does not apply to those who are employees under the terms of this chapter. (c) The penalty for violation of section 6-11 and this section 6-12 shall be as follows: (1) For the first offense, a fine or civil penalty of $500.00, and a suspension of the license issued pursuant to this chapter relating to the location where the offense occurred for a period of 30 days. (2) For the second offense, a fine or civil penalty of $500.00 and a suspension of license issued pursuant to this chapter relating to the location where the offense occurred for a period of 60 days. (3) For the third offense, a fine or civil penalty of $1,000.00 and a permanent revocation of license relating to the location where the offense occurred. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-124; Ord. of 2-22-96; Mo. of 12-3-97, § 4) Sec. 6-13. - Purchase or possession by underage persons. (a) No person under the age of 21 years of age shall purchase or knowingly possess any alcoholic beverage. (b) No person under the age of 21 years of age shall attempt to purchase any alcoholic beverage or misrepresent his age in any manner whatever for the purpose of obtaining alcoholic beverages. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-125) Sec. 6-14. - Gambling in licensed premises prohibited. There shall be no gambling, betting, games of chance, punchboards, slot machines, pinball machines, or the operation of any scheme for hazarding money or any other thing of value, with the exception of the official state lottery, in any place, or any room adjoining the place, leased or controlled by a licensee. Any violation of this section shall be cause for suspension or revocation of a license. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-126) State Law reference— Georgia Lottery for Education Act, O.C.G.A. § 50-27-1 et seq. Sec. 6-15. - Regulations for employees. The following regulations shall apply to all establishments holding a license for consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises: (1) An employee shall meet the same character requirements as set forth in this chapter for the licensee, except for the residency requirements. (2) No person shall be employed to sell, serve, or mix alcoholic beverages by an establishment holding a license pursuant to this chapter until such person has been fingerprinted and cleared by the county sheriff, indicating that the person is eligible for such employment. (3) No permit shall be issued until such time as a signed application has been filed with the county sheriff, and a search of the criminal record of the applicant completed. The application shall include, but shall not be limited to, the name, date of birth, and prior arrest record of the applicant, though the fact of an arrest record shall be used for investigative purposes only, and shall give rise to no presumption or inference of guilt. Due to the inclusion of arrest information, these applications shall be regarded as confidential and shall not be produced for public inspection without a court order. (4) The county sheriff shall have a complete and exhaustive search made relative to any police record of the person fingerprinted or cleared. If there is no record of a violation of this chapter, the sheriff's department shall notify the board of commissioners, who shall issue a permit to the employee, stating that the person is eligible for employment. If it is found that the person fingerprinted or cleared is not eligible for employment, the sheriff shall notify the board of commissioners, who shall notify the employer that this person is not eligible for employment. (5) It shall be the duty of all persons, holding any license to sell alcoholic beverages, to file with the board of commissioners the name of the establishment, the license number and a list of all employees, with their home addresses and home telephone numbers, twice annually on or before June 1 and again on or before December 1. (6) All permits issued through administrative error or through an error in completion of a background investigation can be terminated by the board of commissioners. (7) This section shall not be construed to include employees whose duties are limited solely to those of busboy, cook, or dishwasher. (8) No licensee shall allow any employee, required to hold a permit, to work on the licensed premises unless the licensee has on file, on the premises, the current, valid permit of such employee. (9) If any permit holder leaves the employ of a licensed establishment, the licensee shall immediately surrender his permit to the board of commissioners. (10) All permits issued pursuant to this chapter remain the property of the county and shall be produced for inspection upon the demand of the board of commissioners. (11) Separate permits are required for each employee working in more than one establishment serving alcoholic beverages. (12) All applications shall be sworn to by the applicant before a notary public or other officer empowered by law to administer oaths. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-127; Mo. of 6-4-97) Sec. 6-16. - Open area and patio sales. (a) Alcoholic beverage sales can be made by a licensed consumption on-premises establishment in a patio/open-area-type environment if the establishment has been approved to do so by the board of commissioners. (b) The requirement for approval is that the patio/open area be enclosed by some structure providing for public ingress/egress only through the main licensed premises. The purpose of this requirement is to prevent a customer from leaving the outside sales area with an open drink without the licensee's knowledge. (c) The height of such structure shall be a minimum of four feet above ground level. It does not have to be solid, nor does it have to restrict visibility into or out of the patio/open sales area. It must be permitted and approved by the county's building inspection department and the county's fire department as required by their governing regulations or codes. (d) The only exit from this type of area is to be through the licensed establishment's main premises and through an approved fire exit, not for general public use unless an emergency exists. The fire exit should be of the type that sounds an alarm so that the establishment will be alerted in the event of unauthorized use when no emergency exists. (e) If a licensee desires a patio/open sales area inside an existing structure, plans will be reviewed and approved on an individual basis by the board of commissioners. Interior type patio/open sales areas must also meet the requirements of the county's development and fire codes. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-128) Sec. 6-17. - No outside the premises consumption. (a) It is prohibited for customers to leave the premises with open alcoholic beverages, and it is the licensee's responsibility to ensure that no open beverages are sold and carried out. (b) It is prohibited for customers to gather outside an alcoholic beverage establishment and consume alcoholic beverages. (c) It is prohibited for the manager or any employee to allow persons to gather outside an alcoholic beverage establishment and consume alcoholic beverages. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-129) Sec. 6-18. - Solicitation of drinks prohibited. No retail-consumption dealer, licensed pursuant to this chapter, shall require, permit, suffer, encourage, or induce any employee or person to solicit in the licensed premises for himself, or for any person other than the patron and guest of the patron, the purchase by the patron of any drink, whether alcoholic beverage or nonalcoholic beverage or money with which to purchase the beverage; nor shall any licensee pay a commission or any other compensation to any person frequenting his establishment, or to his agent or manager to solicit for himself, or for others, the purchase by the patron of any drink, whether alcoholic beverage or nonalcoholic beverage or money with which to purchase the beverage; nor shall any licensee pay a commission or any other compensation to any person frequenting his establishment or to his agent or manager to solicit for himself for others, the purchase by the patron of any drink, whether alcoholic beverage or nonalcoholic. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-130) Sec. 6-19. - Noise from establishments prohibited. Noise will not be allowed that can be heard outside the physical boundaries of establishments licensed under this chapter. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-131) Sec. 6-20. - Inspection of licensed establishments by law enforcement personnel. Any and all law enforcement officers, including county police, shall have the authority to inspect establishments licensed under this chapter during the hours in which the premises are open for business. These inspections shall be made for the purpose of verifying compliance with the requirements of this chapter and state law. This section is not intended to limit the authority of any other county officer to conduct inspections authorized by other provisions of law. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-132) Sec. 6-21. - "Happy hour" promotions prohibited. (a) No licensee or employee or agent of a licensee shall engage in any of the following practices in connection with the sale or other disposition of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises: (1) The giving away of any alcoholic beverages in conjunction with the sale of any other alcoholic beverage. (2) The sale of two or more alcoholic beverages for a single price, including the sale of all such beverages a customer can or desires to drink at a single price. (3) Selling, offering to sell, or delivering to any person any alcoholic beverage at a price less than one-half the price customarily charged for such alcoholic beverage, provided nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prohibit reducing the price of a drink by up to one-half the price customarily charged. (4) Requiring or allowing the purchase of a second or subsequent alcoholic beverage at the same time another alcoholic beverage is purchased or before the first beverage has been consumed, by any one person. (5) Increase the volume of alcoholic beverage contained in a drink without proportionately increasing the price customarily charged for such beverage. (b) It is the intent of this section to prohibit activities typically associated with promotions referred to as "happy hour." (c) As used in this section, the phrase "customarily charged" means the price regularly charged for such alcoholic beverage during the same calendar week. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-138) Sec. 6-22. - Brown-bagging prohibited. It is prohibited for any person to bring in his own alcoholic beverage (brown bag) in any establishment either licensed or unlicensed to serve alcoholic beverages. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 8-101) Sec. 6-23. - Hours for wholesalers. Wholesalers shall not engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages except between 6:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 7-104) Sec. 6-24. - Nonprofit organizations temporary license. Any nonprofit organization may be issued a temporary permit for a period not to exceed five days in any one year. The nonprofit organization must make application and pay the fee required by section 6-203. Such organization shall be required to comply with all the general ordinances and the license and regulations for a consumption on the premises establishment with the exception of the full service kitchen requirement. (Res. of 2-16-95) Secs. 6-25—6-45. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LICENSING GENERALLY
Sec. 6-46. - Sale in unincorporated area of county; license a privilege. (a) Alcoholic beverages may be sold in the unincorporated area of the county under a license granted by the board of commissioners upon the terms and conditions provided in this article. (b) All licenses in this article shall be a mere grant of privilege to carry on the business during the term of the licenses, subject to all terms and conditions imposed by this article and state law. (c) All licenses pursuant to this article shall have printed on the front these words: "This license is a mere privilege, subject to be revoked and annulled, and is subject to any future ordinances which may be enacted." (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-101) Sec. 6-47. - Sale or possession for purpose of sale without license or beyond boundaries of premises covered by license. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or possess for the purpose of sale any alcoholic beverage, where the person does not have a license from the county to sell or possess for sale these alcoholic beverages, or to sell or make deliveries beyond the boundaries of the premises covered by the license. (b) Violations of this section shall, upon conviction, be punishable as provided in section 1-13. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-104) Sec. 6-48. - Separate application and license for each location of sale. A separate application must be made for each location, and a separate license must be issued. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-105) Sec. 6-49. - Application. (a) All persons desiring to sell alcoholic beverages shall make application on the form prescribed by the board of commissioners. (b) The application shall include, but shall not be limited to: the name and address of the applicant; the proposed business to be carried on; if a partnership, the names and residence addresses of the partners; if a corporation, the names of the officers; the name and address of the registered agent for service of process; the name of the manager; the names and addresses of all shareholders, and the name of any other entity having a financial interest in each entity which is to own or operate the establishment for which a license is sought. If the manager changes, the applicant must furnish the governing authority and the county sheriff's department the name and address of the new manager and other information as requested within ten days of such change. (c) All applicants shall furnish data, fingerprints, financial responsibility, and other records as required by the board of commissioners to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article. Failure to furnish data pursuant to such request shall automatically serve to dismiss the application with prejudice. (d) All applications shall be sworn to by the applicant before a notary public or other officer empowered by law to administer oaths. (e) In all instances in which an application is denied under the provisions of this article, the applicant may not reapply for a license for at least one year from the final date of denial. (f) The board of commissioners shall provide written notice to any applicant whose application is denied under the provisions of this article. Such written notification shall set forth in reasonable detail the reasons for such denial and shall advise the applicant of the right to appeal to the board of commissioners for a hearing. Any such hearing shall be conducted with the same requirements set forth in section 6-59. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-106) Sec. 6-49.1. - Consideration of application; approval conditional. Each application provided for in this article shall be considered and passed upon by the board in regular or special session, legally assembled. No license shall be granted to any person unless it is made to appear to the board that the applicant is a suitable and fit person to carry on such business, and that the business will be conducted in an orderly manner and in compliance with all laws, municipal, state and federal. Upon approval of the application and payment of the required license fee, the applicant shall be entitled to the issuance of the license; provided however, the board reserves the right to approve such issuance of the license or licenses conditioned upon full and final compliance by the licensee with all applicable county ordinances. (Ord. of 3-5-14, pt. II) Sec. 6-49.2. - Direct financial interest restricted. No person who has a direct financial interest in a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages at wholesale shall hold any license or have an interest in any other license issued under the terms of this article. (Ord. of 3-5-14, pt. II) Sec. 6-50. - Detailed plans of building in which business will be located must be submitted. (a) No retail alcoholic beverage license shall be issued to any person unless the building in which the business will be located is complete, and detailed plans of the building and outside premises are attached to the application, or unless proposed plans and specifications and a building permit of a proposed building to be built are attached to the application. The completed building or the proposed building shall comply with all regulations of the state revenue commissioner, the state fire marshal, and the laws of the state. The proposed building may also be subject to final inspection and approval, when completed, by the county building inspector. Each building in which the business will be located shall contain sufficient lighting so that the building itself and the premises on all sides are readily visible at all times from the front of the street on which the building is located, so as to reveal the inside retail area of a package sale business building, and so as to reveal all of the outside premises of all buildings. In a package sale business, no screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or thing shall be permitted in the window or upon the doors of such licensed premises which shall prevent a clear view into the interior of such premises from the street or road at all times. No booth, screen, partition, or other obstruction shall be permitted within the interior of such packaged licensed premises. All premises for which a consumption on the premises license shall be issued shall afford therein adequate sanitary toilet facilities and shall be adequately illuminated so that all hallways, passageways, and open areas may be clearly seen by customers therein. (b) Each applicant for a retail alcoholic beverage license shall attach to his application evidence of ownership of the building or proposed building, or a copy of the lease, if an applicant is leasing the building.
