(c) Each applicant for a retail alcoholic beverage license shall attach to his application evidence of an approved certificate of occupancy issued by the proper authority or proof that no certificate of occupancy is required. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-107; Mo. of 12-3-97, § 5) Sec. 6-51. - Advertising in official gazette of county and on-premises. (a) (1) A notice of each application to sell alcoholic beverages at retail shall be advertised in the official gazette of the county, once a week for four weeks immediately preceding the meeting of the governing authority at which the application is to be considered, using the form set out as Exhibit A. Exhibit A The following are the wording and specifications of the newspaper advertisement which must be published four times in the legal gazette (McDuffie Progress) during the 30-day period prior to the hearing of the application by the county commission. NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN THAT THE OWNER OF ____________ LOCATED AT ____________ WILL APPLY TO THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR A LICENSE FOR THE SALE OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES (SELECT ONLY ONE: FOR CONSUMPTIONON THE PREMISES OR BY THE PACKAGE THE PACKAGE ON THE PREMISES) 30 DAYS AFTER THE FIRST PUBLIC NOTICE.
(2) Applicant is responsible to show proof of four newspaper advertisements by affidavit of publisher or his designate and is responsible for expenses incurred in such publication. (b) (1) Further, there shall be a sign posted 30 days prior to the hearing of the application in a prominent position on the property, Using the form and specifications prescribed according to Exhibit B. Exhibit B The following is the wording and specifications of a sign which must be posted when applying for a new license for the sale of alcoholic beverages: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN THAT THE OWNER OF THIS ESTABLISHMENT WILL APPLY TO THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR A LICENSE FOR THE SALE OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES (SELECT ONLY ONE: FOR CONSUMPTION ON THE PREMISES OR BY THE PACKAGE ON THE PREMISES) 30 DAYS AFTER THE POSTING OF THIS NOTICE.
This sign must be a minimum size of 2½ square feet with letters of a minimum size of two inches. (2) Prior to approval of the license, applicant shall provide proof this section has been satisfied in a manner suitable to the county and applicant shall provide a sworn statement to the county that this provision has been complied with. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-108; Mo. of 1-7-04(2)) Sec. 6-52. - Qualifications of applicant for license. (a) No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be granted to any person who is not a citizen of the United States or alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence. (b) Where the applicant is a partnership or corporation, the provisions of this section shall apply to all its partners, officers, managers and stockholders. (c) No person shall be granted a license unless it shall appear to the satisfaction of the board that such person shall be of good moral character or, in the case of an entity which is not a natural person, that such entity has a good reputation, and in no event shall a license be granted to any person who has been convicted or has pled guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any charge involving a crime or moral turpitude, gambling or illegal possession or sale of controlled substances or illegal possession of alcoholic beverages within a period of ten years immediately prior to the filing of such application. (d) No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be granted to any person convicted under any federal, state, or local law of any felony, within ten years prior to the filing of the application for such license. (e) It shall be unlawful for any county officer, employee, or his spouse or minor children, to have any whole, partial or beneficial interest in any license to sell alcoholic beverages in the county. (f) No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be granted to any person who has had any license issued under the police powers of the county previously revoked within two years prior to the filing of the application. (g) The board of commissioners may decline to issue a license when any person having any interest in the operation of such place of business or control over such place of business does not meet the same character requirements as set forth in this section for the licensee. (h) All licensed establishments must have and continuously maintain in the state, a registered agent upon whom any process, notice, or demand, required or permitted by law or under this chapter to be served upon the licensee or owner, may be served. Licensee shall file the name, address, and telephone number of such agent, along with the written consent to serve of such agent with the governing authority and shall be in such form as it may prescribe. (i) An application for license under this article may be denied where it appears to the board that the applicant does not have adequate financial strength, adequate financial participation in the proposed business to direct and manage its affairs, or where it appears that the applicant is intended or is likely to be a surrogate for a person who would not otherwise qualify for a license under this article. (j) The board, in its discretion, may consider any extenuating circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, the application or the proposed location of the establishment, including, but not limited to, traffic congestion, general character of the neighborhood, or the effect the location would have on adjacent and surrounding properties and/or neighborhoods. If, in the board's judgment, circumstances are such that issuing of a license under this article would not be in the best interest of the general public, such circumstances may be grounds for denying the application. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-109; Res. of 11-15-94; Ord. of 3-5-14, pts. III, IV) Sec. 6-53. - License fee scale. Before a license shall be granted, the applicant therefor shall comply with all rules and regulations adopted by the board of commissioners regulating the sale of alcoholic beverages, and each applicant shall pay a license fee in accordance with the scale fixed, from time to time, by the board of commissioners and contained in section 6-203 and kept on file in the office of the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-111) Sec. 6-54. - Display of license at place of business. The county alcoholic beverage license shall at all times be kept plainly exposed to view to the public at the place of business of the licensee. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-112) Sec. 6-55. - Transferability of license. (a) No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be transferable, except as otherwise provided in this article. (b) In case of the death of a licensee, the establishment shall be allowed to continue to sell alcoholic beverages for a period of 45 days from the date of death, or until expiration of the license, or until approval of a new licensee, whichever shall first occur; provided that no sale of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed until such time as a personal representative of the estate, appointed by a probate court of competent jurisdiction, shall make application for authorization with the board of commissioners. (c) If a license is surrendered, or a licensee severs his association with a licensed establishment, the establishment may continue to sell alcoholic beverages for a period of 45 days from the date of surrender or from the date of severance, provided no such sale shall be authorized until such time as a new application for a license is made, such application indicating that no change of ownership has occurred, except as excepted in this section. Upon issuance of a new license, the authorization to sell under the previous license shall be revoked by operation of law. No additional license fees shall be required during the period for which the original license was issued. (d) Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one or more of the partners holding a license to withdraw from the partnership in favor of one or more of the partners who were partners at the time of the issuance of the license. This section shall not prohibit transfer of stock between persons who held stock in the corporate ownership at the time of issuance of the license nor shall it prohibit transfer of stock which does not result in any person increasing his stock holdings to a total of ten percent or more of any class of stock. (e) Should a transfer of location be approved, with no change of ownership of the business, the license fee paid for the old location shall be applied to the new location. (f) Except as provided in this section, any change in the ownership of the business shall cancel and revoke any license issued pursuant to this article automatically, without the necessity of any hearing. (g) Violation of this section shall result in revocation of the license being used, and a fine on the new ownership and the old ownership of $500.00. No license will be issued to the old or the new owner in the county for one year from the date of the violation. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-113) Sec. 6-56. - Automatic license forfeiture for nonuse. Any holder of any license issued pursuant to this article who shall for a period of three consecutive months after the license has been issued cease to operate the business and sale of the product or products authorized shall, after the three-month period, automatically forfeit the license without the necessity of any further action. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-114) Sec. 6-57. - License expiration; renewal. (a) All licenses granted pursuant to this article shall expire on December 31 of each year. Licensees who desire to renew their licenses shall file application with the requisite fee with the board of commissioners on the form provided for renewal of the license for the ensuing year. Applications for renewal must be filed before November 30 of each year; otherwise, investigative and administrative costs, penalties, and interest will be assessed. No renewal license shall be granted after January 1, but such application shall be treated as an initial application, and the applicant shall be required to comply with all rules and regulations for the granting of licenses as if no previous license had been held. (b) All licenses granted pursuant to this article shall be for a calendar year, and the full license fee must be paid for any license application filed prior to July 1 of the license year. A full license fee must be paid for a beer and wine license application filed after July 1 of the license year. One-half of a full license fee shall be paid for a distilled spirit license application filed after July 1 of the license year. License fees are not refundable. (c) Any person renewing any license issued pursuant to this article, who shall pay the required fee, or any portion thereof, after the date set by law for such payment, shall, in addition to the annual fee, pay a late charge of 20 percent and shall pay simple interest on the delinquent balance at the annual rate then charged by the Internal Revenue Service of the United States on unpaid federal income taxes. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-115) Sec. 6-58. - Suspension or revocation of license. (a) A license may be suspended or revoked by the board of commissioners where the licensee furnishes fraudulent or untruthful information in the application for a license, and for failure to pay all fees, taxes, or other charges imposed under the provisions of this article. (b) Whenever the state shall revoke any permit or license to sell alcoholic beverages, the county license shall thereupon be automatically revoked. The board of commissioners, upon notice of this revocation from the state, shall take the necessary steps to see that signs are removed and that all alcoholic beverage sales cease. (c) Any licensed establishment that is found to be in violation of section 6-18 shall be subject to immediate license revocation. (d) The board of commissioners shall revoke the license of any licensee who shall have been found to have violated this article three or more times. (e) The board of commissioners shall revoke the license for any premises where alcoholic beverages have been sold or distributed during a period of suspension. (f) The board of commissioners may suspend or revoke the license of any establishment which does not meet the licensing qualifications set forth in this article at any time such knowledge becomes known to it. (g) An act or omission of a licensee, stockholder, or employee of the licensee or licensed establishment, willingly or knowingly performed, which constitutes a violation of federal or state law, or of any provision of this article, will subject the licensee to suspension or revocation of its license in accordance with the provisions of this article, when the board of commissioners determines to its satisfaction that the act or omission did occur, regardless of whether any criminal prosecution or conviction ensues. (h) Whenever it can be shown that a licensee under this article no longer maintains adequate financial responsibility upon which issuance of the license was conditioned, or whenever the licensee has defaulted in any obligation of any kind whatsoever, lawfully owing to the county, a license may be revoked. (i) A license may be revoked if the licensee or the majority stockholder of the corporation holding a license moves his residence from the county. For the purposes of this subsection, the residence will be presumed to have been removed from the county if the licensee does not live therein more than six months per year. (j) Any license may be revoked due to any conduct on the part of the licensee or his employees for the operating or conducting of a business in a manner that is contrary to the public welfare, safety, health or morals, or in such a manner as to constitute a nuisance. (k) Any licensed establishment that is found to be in violation of sections 6-11 and 6-12 shall be subject to immediate license suspension or revocation. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-133; Mo. of 12-3-97, § 6) Sec. 6-59. - Hearings for denial, suspension or revocation of license. (a) Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, or unless waived by the licensee, no license under this article shall be suspended or revoked without the opportunity for a hearing as provided in this section. (b) The county code enforcement official shall provide written notice to the licensee of the initiation of an action to suspend or revoke a license. Such written notification shall set forth, in reasonable detail, the reasons for such action and shall notify the licensee of the right to a hearing under the provisions of this section. Any licensee against whom action for the suspension or revocation of a license is initiated may have a hearing concerning such action before the board. Such hearing shall be by written request, filed in the office of the clerk of commission within ten days after the date of the notice of the initiation from the licensee. Such written request shall set forth the reasons why the licensee feels that the proposed action should not be taken and, in reasonable detail, the grounds and facts which the licensee contends support the licensee's position. The board shall determine whether or not the license shall be temporarily suspended during the period prior to the hearing and until action is taken by the board. Failure of the licensee to request a hearing within the time specified shall be deemed to be a waiver by the licensee of a right to a hearing and the board shall be authorized to proceed with final action on the matter without the holding of a hearing. (c) A hearing, if requested, shall be held within 14 days of the date of filing the request for a hearing. At such hearing the licensee shall have the right to be represented by an attorney, at the expense of the licensee, and to present evidence and cross-examine witnesses. (d) The hearing need not be at a regular meeting of the commissioners but may be at such time and place as shall be fixed by the notice. (e) The decision of the board shall be by a majority vote of the members present at the hearing. (f) Within three days from the date of the hearing, the board shall render a decision in writing and furnish a copy of the decision to the licensee by any means available. The decision of the board shall be effective immediately. (g) The action of the board or its committee shall be final when taken. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-134; Mo. of 6-4-97; Mo. of 12-3-97, § 7; Ord. of 3-5-14, pt. III) Sec. 6-60. - Notice of charge and hearing. For the purpose of this article, notice shall be deemed delivered when personally served by certified mail, within three days after the date of deposit in the United States mail to the address given in the application for the license. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2-135; Mo. of 12-3-97, § 8) Secs. 6-61—6-80. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - RETAIL SALES OF DISTILLED SPIRITS FOR CONSUMPTION ON-PREMISES
Sec. 6-81. - Locations where permitted. No distilled spirits may be sold by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold, except in restaurants, nightclubs, lounges, and private clubs. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 3-101) Sec. 6-82. - Investigative and administrative costs paid for by license applicant. Each application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of the license fee, together with a nonrefundable separate check or cash in the amount of $100.00 to defray investigative and administrative costs. If the applicant is denied a state license, or if for any other reason the applicant is denied a license, the deposit representing the license fee shall be refunded, but the $100.00 cost paid for investigation and administrative cost shall be retained; provided, however, that any person applying for more than one license shall pay only one fee to defray investigative and administrative expenses, which fee shall be the largest of the investigative and administrative fees authorized under this article. Any applicant for a license under this article who has in existence at the time of making the new application an existing license under this article shall pay no investigative and administrative costs. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 3-102) Sec. 6-83. - Hours and days of sale. Distilled spirits shall not be sold for consumption on the premises at any of the following times: (1) At any time on Christmas day, Thanksgiving day, or Sunday. (2) At any time in violation of a local resolution, ordinance, or regulation or special order of the board of commissioners. (3) At any time or place prohibited by state law or by regulations of the state revenue commissioner. (4) On any Monday through Friday before 8:00 a.m. or after 3:00 a.m.; on Saturday before 8:00 a.m. or after 1:55 a.m. on Sunday mornings (EST or EDT whichever shall be applicable). (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 3-103; Ord. of 1-15-08, § 1) Sec. 6-84. - Consumption sales only. Persons holding a license to sell distilled spirits for consumption on the premises shall not be permitted to sell liquor by the package or bottle in the premises licensed for consumption. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 3-104; Res. of 12-6-00) Sec. 6-85. - Beer and wine consumption permitted, if licensed. A licensee for the sale of distilled spirits for consumption on the premises shall also have the right to serve beer and wine, provided he shall secure a license therefor. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 3-105) Secs. 6-86—6-105. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - RETAIL SALES OF MALT BEVERAGES AND WINE FOR CONSUMPTION ON-PREMISES
Sec. 6-106. - Type of retail establishments where permitted. No beer or wine shall be sold for consumption on the premises where sold, except in restaurants, nightclubs, lounges, taverns, and private clubs. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 4-101) Sec. 6-107. - License fee and investigative and administrative costs to accompany application. (a) Each application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable check or cash in the amount of $100.00 to defray investigative and administrative costs. (b) If the application is denied and the license refused, or if the applicant withdraws his application prior to its being issued, the license fee shall be refunded but the $100.00 cost paid for investigation shall be retained. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 4-102) Sec. 6-108. - Hours and days of sale. Beer and/or wine shall not be sold for consumption on the premises: (1) At any time on Christmas day, Thanksgiving day, or Sunday. (2) At any time in violation of a local resolution, ordinance, or regulation or special order of the board of commissioners. (3) At any time or place prohibited by state law or by regulations of the state revenue commissioner. (4) On any Monday through Friday before 8:00 a.m. or after 3:00 a.m.; on Saturday before 8:00 a.m. or after 1:55 a.m. on Sunday mornings (EST or EDT whichever shall be applicable). (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 4-103; Mo. of 3-1-00; Ord. of 1-15-08, § 1) Sec. 6-109. - Package sales prohibited. Persons holding a license to sell beer and wine for consumption on the premises shall not be permitted to sell beer and wine by the package in the premises licensed for consumption. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 4-104; Res. of 12-6-00) Secs. 6-110—6-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - RETAIL PACKAGE SALES OF DISTILLED SPIRITS
Sec. 6-131. - Types of establishments where permitted. (a) No distilled spirits by the package shall be sold at retail except in: (1) Retail establishments devoted exclusively to the retail sale of alcoholic beverages by the package; (2) Retail establishments in which space has been set aside, devoted exclusively to the retail sale of distilled spirits by the package, with ingress and egress provided directly to and only to the exterior of the building in which the facility is located and not to any other enclosed part of the building in which the facility is located, except as provided in subsection (a)(3) of this section; or (3) Hotels, motels, and office buildings where every public entrance to this use shall be from a lobby, hallway, or other interior portion of the primary use structure. (b) Nothing in this section shall prohibit the retail sale within these establishments of liquid commodities and mixes normally used in the preparation and serving of distilled spirits. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 5-101) Sec. 6-132. - Coin-operated or amusement machines prohibited on-premises; exception. No retail dealer in liquors shall permit on his premises any slot machines of any kind or character or any coin-operated machines or any machine operated for amusement purposes. However, cigarette vending machines may be permitted. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 5-102) Sec. 6-133. - Hours of sale. Retail package licensees shall not engage in the sale of spirituous liquors at any of the following times: (1) On Christmas day, Thanksgiving day, or Sunday. (2) Any time in violation of local resolution, ordinance, or regulation or special order of the board of commissioners. (3) At any time or place prohibited by state law or by regulations of the state revenue commissioner. (4) Before 8:00 a.m. or after 11:45 p.m. (EST or EDT as applicable) on Monday through Saturday. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 5-103; Ord. of 1-15-08, § 1) Sec. 6-134. - Investigative and administrative cost paid by license applicant. Each application for license under this article shall be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of the license fee, together with a separate check or cash in the amount of $100.00 to defray investigative and administrative cost. If the application is denied and the license is refused or if the applicant is denied a state license, the deposit representing the license fee shall be refunded, but the $100.00 cost paid for investigative and administrative cost shall be retained. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 5-104) Sec. 6-135. - Information concerning interests of other persons to be declared. (a) All applications for package liquor licenses, both original and renewals, must be accompanied by a full and complete statement, under oath, of information relative to any and all interest in retail liquor stores. This shall include names and addresses of all persons possessing a legal ownership in the subject establishment, together with any interest each person or any immediate relative has in any other retail store located in the county or any other place; the ownership of the land and the building where this retail business is operated; the amount of rental paid of this land building, the manner in which such rental is determined, and to whom and at what intervals the rental is paid; the names and addresses, by affidavit from the owner, lessor or sub-lessor of the land and building, of all persons having any whole, partial, beneficial or other legal interest in and to the land and building on and in which this retail liquor store is located; and any other information called for by the board of commissioners to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article. (b) Any change in relationship declared in this section must be filed when made with the board of commissioners, and failure to so file within a period of ten days after this change is made shall be grounds for the board of commissioners to cancel the license. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 5-105) Sec. 6-136. - No consumption on licensed premises permitted. No establishment holding a package liquor license shall sell, offer to sell, possess, or permit the consumption on the licensed premises of any kind of alcoholic or spirituous or venous liquors or beverages, the sale or the possession of which is not authorized by this article. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 5-106) Secs. 6-137—6-155. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - RETAIL PACKAGE SALES OF MALT BEVERAGES AND WINE
Sec. 6-156. - Type of retail establishment where permitted. No beer and/or wine shall be sold in package at retail except in establishments licensed under this article. No establishment holding a package beer and wine license shall sell, offer to sell, possess, or permit the consumption on the licensed premises for any kind of alcoholic or spirituous or venous liquors or beverages, the sale or possession of which is not authorized by this article. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 6-101) Sec. 6-157. - Hours of sale. Retail package licensees shall not engage in the sale of beer and/or wine at any of the following times: (1) On Christmas day, Thanksgiving day, or Sunday. (2) Any time in violation of local resolution, ordinance, or regulation or special order of the board of commissioners. (3) At any time or place prohibited by state law or by regulations of the state revenue commissioner. (4) Before 12:01 a.m. on Monday, or after 12:00 midnight Saturday. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 6-102; Ord. of 1-15-08, § 1) Sec. 6-158. - Use of tags or labels to indicate prices. Retailers shall indicate plainly by tags or labels on the bottles or containers or on the shelf immediately below where the containers are placed the prices of all beer and wine exposed or offered for sale. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 6-103) Sec. 6-159. - License fee and investigative and administrative costs to accompany application. Each application for license under this article shall be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of the license fee, together with a separate check or cash in the amount of $100.00 to defray investigative and administrative costs. If the application is denied and a license refused, or if the applicant withdraws his application prior to its being issued, the license fee shall be refunded but the $100.00 cost paid for investigation shall be retained. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 6-104) Sec. 6-160. - No consumption on-premises permitted. No establishment holding a package beer and wine license shall sell, offer to sell, process, or permit the consumption on the licensed premises of any kind of alcoholic or spirituous or venous liquors or beverages, the sale or the possession of which is not authorized by this article. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 6-105) Secs. 6-161—6-180. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - WHOLESALE DISTRIBUTORS
Sec. 6-181. - Special provisions applicable to wholesale license. (a) Any person desiring to sell at wholesale any alcoholic beverages in unincorporated areas of the county shall make application to the board of commissioners for a license to do so, which application shall be in writing on the prescribed forms, and pay any license as set by the board of commissioners. (b) No person who has any direct financial interest in a license for the retail sale of distilled spirits shall be allowed to have any interest or ownership in any wholesale distilled spirit license. (c) No retailer shall purchase any alcoholic beverage from any person other than a wholesaler licensed under this article. No wholesaler shall sell any distilled spirits to any person other than a retailer licensed under this article. (d) No alcoholic beverage shall be delivered to any retail sales outlet in the county except by a duly licensed wholesaler. The name of the wholesaler distributor shall be clearly marked on the delivery vehicle. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 7-101) Secs. 6-182—6-200. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - EXCISE TAXES AND LICENSE FEES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 78.
Sec. 6-201. - Excise tax; bond required on wholesalers. (a) There is hereby imposed an excise tax upon all alcoholic beverages purchased by persons holding retail package licenses and/or consumption on the premises licenses at a rate set by the board of commissioners. (b) The excise tax shall be collected by all wholesale dealers selling alcoholic beverages to persons holding retail licenses and shall be paid by the wholesale dealers to the board of commissioners by the tenth of each month, based on the units of alcohol sold during the previous month. Interest shall accrue on late payments at a rate equal to the then rate charged by the Internal Revenue Service on delinquent income taxes. The wholesale dealer shall keep true and correct records of all sales and shipments. The monthly remittance shall be accompanied by a sworn statement showing but not limited to the type and volume sold to each retail licensee on a form or in a format as approved by the board of commissioners. (c) Each wholesale dealer, prior to commencement of business operation in the county, shall post a performance bond with the board of commissioners equal to 1½ times the estimated highest monthly payment made in a calendar year of the excise tax, based on sales collected by the wholesale dealer for the retailers to secure the payments for the tax imposed in this section. These bonds shall be secured by cash which shall bear no interest, or a surety bond executed by a surety company licensed to do business in this state and approved by the board of commissioners. (d) A wholesaler may be excused from posting the performance bond as provided in this section after demonstrating full and satisfactory compliance with the provisions required under this article for a period of 12 months subsequent to the commencement of business operations within the county. Continued exemption from the requirement of posting the performance bond shall be conditioned upon continued compliance with the terms of this article for the payment of all sums, as required by the provisions in this article. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 7-102) Sec. 6-202. - Audit by board of commissioners. The board of commissioners shall have the right to audit each wholesale dealer licensed to do business in the county. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 7-103) Sec. 6-203. - License fees enumerated. (a) License fees applicable to this chapter are set out as follows: (1) Retail dealers of distilled spirits to be consumed on the premises, $2,000.00 per year. (2) Retail dealers of beer and/or wine to be consumed on the premises, $500.00 for the first year, and $300.00 for each succeeding year. (3) Retail dealers of distilled spirits sold in original package for consumption off the premises, $2,000.00 per year. (4) Retail dealers of beer and/or wine sold in original package for consumption off the premises, $500.00 for the first year, and $300.00 for each year thereafter. (5) Wholesaler dealers in beer and/or wine, the maximum amount at any time allowed by O.C.G.A. § 3-5-43. (6) Wholesale dealers in distilled spirits, $2,000.00 per year. (7) Distilled spirits wholesale dealers' excise tax: $0.22 per liter and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. (8) Wholesale wine dealers' excise tax: $0.22 per liter and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. (9) Wholesale malt beverage dealers' excise tax: Where malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, are sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, a tax of $6.00 on each container sold containing not more than 15½ gallons and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 15½ gallons sold. (10) Nonprofit organizations, temporary: $100.00. (b) Where malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans, or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $0.05 per 12 ounces and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces. (Ord. of 6-1-89, § 10-101; Ord. of 10-19-93; Res. of 12-1-93; Res. of 2-16-95) Secs. 6-204—6-225. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - OPEN CONTAINERS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Possession of open container of alcoholic beverage while operating vehicle, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-253.
Sec. 6-226. - Title of article. This article shall be known as the "McDuffie County Open Container Ordinance." (Ord. of 5-3-89, § 1) Sec. 6-227. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Broken package means a bottle, can, keg or other original container which has been opened, or the seal to which has been broken, so as to allow the contents thereof to be immediately consumed. Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled. Occupant means any person who is occupying any vehicle on a public street, road or public place. Open container means a glass, cup, jar, can or other receptacle designed for or capable of being used to hold liquids. Street or road means the entire width between the right-of-way lines publicly maintained when any part thereof is opened to the use of the public for vehicular traffic. (Ord. of 5-3-89, § 2) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 6-228. - Operation or occupancy of motor vehicle while possessing; exceptions. (a) By operator. It shall be a violation of this article to operate a motor vehicle on a public road or street in the unincorporated area of the county, while the operator or any occupant thereof has in his possession an open container or broken package containing alcoholic beverages. (b) By occupant. It shall be a violation of this article for any occupant of a motor vehicle being driven on a public road or street in the unincorporated area of the county to possess an open container or broken package containing alcoholic beverages. (c) Exceptions. (1) This article shall not apply to the passengers in any chartered bus designed for carrying more than ten persons when it is being used for the transportations of persons, or a passenger in a chauffeured limousine driven by a person holding a valid chauffeur's license issued by the state, which limousine service in addition has a valid county or City of Thomson business license, or to the occupants of living quarters of a camper or motor home. (2) This article shall not apply to broken packages contained in a locked compartment of a motor vehicle. (Ord. of 5-3-89, § 3) Sec. 6-229. - Possession upon public streets and roads while afoot. It shall be a violation of this article for any person on foot to be about or upon the public streets and roads of the county while having in his possession an open container or broken package containing alcoholic beverages. (Ord. of 5-3-89, § 4)

div.head: Chapter 10 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Health and sanitation, ch. 38; offenses, ch. 50. State Law reference— Authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const., art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(a)(3); livestock running at large or straying, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; permitting dogs in heat to roam or run free, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-7.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 10-1—10-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DANGEROUS DOG CONTROL
Sec. 10-26. - Enforcement of article. Pursuant to the provisions of the dangerous dog control law of the state (O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.), the county director of animal control is hereby designated dog control officer and shall administer and enforce the provisions of the dangerous dog control law. (Ord. of 12-7-88, § 1) Sec. 10-27. - Creation of animal control board. There is hereby created an animal control board of three members to be appointed for initial terms of one, two and three years, and three years thereafter, to conduct hearings as required by O.C.G.A. § 4-8-24. (Ord. of 12-7-88, § 2) Cross reference— Authorities, boards and commissions, § 2-201 et seq. Sec. 10-28. - Composition and purpose of animal control board. The animal control board shall comprise one representative each from the board of commissioners, city council, and board of health to conduct periodic hearings at the call of the dog control officers, for those dog owners who desire to contest the classification of their dog or dogs as dangerous or potentially dangerous. Sec. 10-29. - Annual fee for dangerous dogs. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall pay an annual fee to the county in the amount of $100.00. (Ord. of 12-7-88, § 3)

div.head: Chapter 14 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note—The McDuffie County Fire Service By-Laws, Policies and Procedures as adopted December 21, 1993, are compiled and published separately by the county. An official copy of such publication is on file in the office of the county clerk. Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; businesses, ch. 18; environment, ch. 34; health and sanitation, ch. 38; historic preservation, ch. 42; land development code, ch. 44; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 46; signs, ch. 62; solid waste, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; subdivisions, ch. 74; taxation, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 82. State Law reference— Authority of city or county to provide codes, including building, housing, plumbing and electrical codes, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(12); statewide application of minimum standard codes, codes requiring adoption by municipality or county, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; enforcement of codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26; providing of fire escapes by building owners, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-50; access to and use of public facilities by physically handicapped persons, O.C.G.A. § 30-3-1 et seq.; authority to repair, close or demolish unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7; county or municipal ordinances relating to unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 14-1. - Technical building and construction codes adopted. The following technical building and construction codes are adopted by reference and may be amended for later editions as required by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs: (1) International Building Code; (2) National Electrical Code; (3) International Fuel Gas Code; (4) International Mechanical Code; (5) International Plumbing Code; (6) International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings; (7) International Energy Conservation Code (Georgia State Minimum Standard Energy Code); (8) International Fire Code; (9) International Swimming Pool and Spa Code. (Ord. of 4-2-86, §§ 701—727; Ord. of 9-3-86, § 1(5)—(7); Ord. of 11-5-86, § 1(1)—(3); Ord. of 5-6-87; Ord. of 10-7-87, § 1; Ord. of 1-6-88; Ord. of 9-6-89; Res. of 5-1-91; Res. of 1-8-92; Ord. of 11-5-14(1)) Editor's note— On March 5, 1997, the McDuffie County Board of Commissioners approved the rules pertaining to swimming pools and recreational waters, cited under §§ 290-5-57-.01—290-5-57-.04 of the Administrative Rules of the Department of Human Resources Public Health. Sec. 14-2. - Provisions saved from repeal. Sections 801 through 903 relating to use of land and placement of structures and sections 1001 through 1701 relating to stormwater runoff management in the county's former land development code, as such sections were numbered prior to the renumbering provision contained in the resolution of January 1, 1991, are not repealed and shall continue in full force and effect, pending a revision of the subject matter by the county. Sec. 14-3. - County exempt from self-inspection of sewer lines by plumbers and utility contractors. The governing authority of McDuffie County, pursuant to Section 3 of Act No. 1046 enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia during the 1996 session of the legislature and signed by the governor on April 25, 1996, does hereby exempt McDuffie County from the provisions of said Act codified as O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26(d). (Res. of 5-21-96) Editor's note— A resolution adopted May 21, 1996, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of substantive provisions of said resolution as § 14-3 herein was at the editor's discretion. Secs. 14-4—14-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - UNFIT BUILDINGS, OPEN WELLS AND POOLS[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Ordinances relating to repair, closing and demolition of dwellings unfit for human habitation, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-11; abatement of nuisances generally, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-1 et seq.; county or municipality ordinances relating to unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9; abatement of hazard from abandoned well or hole, O.C.G.A. § 44-1-14.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 14-26. - Powers of the county to repair, close or demolish. (a) Whenever the board of commissioners finds that any open well, pool, dwelling, building, or structure located in the unincorporated area of the county causes hurt, inconvenience or damage to another, or is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use due to dilapidation and defects increasing the hazard of fire, accidents or other calamities; lack of adequate ventilation, light or sanitary facilities, or other conditions rendering such dwellings, buildings or structures unsafe or unsanitary, or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety or welfare, or otherwise inimical to the welfare of the residents of such county or municipality; or vacant, dilapidated dwellings, buildings or structures in which drug crimes are being committed, power is hereby conferred upon the county to exercise its police power to repair, close, fill in, cover up or demolish the dwellings, buildings, structures, open wells or pools. (b) Whenever there is found upon private property in the unincorporated area of the county, an accumulation of leaves, trash, junk, filth, and unsanitary or unsafe conditions creating a public health hazard or general nuisance to the persons residing in the vicinity, a finding by any governmental health department, health officer, or building inspector that such property is a health or safety hazard shall constitute prima facie evidence that such property is in violation of this article. (c) The exercise of these powers conferred upon the county shall be limited to properties located in the unincorporated areas of the county. (Res. of 1-8-92, § 1(D)) Sec. 14-27. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Closing means securing and causing the dwelling, building or structure to be vacated. Cover means the placing over the top of an open well or pool a casing or cap preventing further access to the open well or pool. Drug crime means an act which is in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-20 et seq., known as the Georgia Controlled Substances Act. Dwellings, buildings, or structures means any building or structure or part thereof used and occupied for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business uses, or intended to be so used and includes any outhouses and appurtenances belonging thereto or usually enjoyed therewith and also includes any buildings or structures of any design. Fill in means the use of dirt, rock, sand, cement, etc., to fill up an open well or pool so that no opening or hole any longer exists. Nuisance means anything that causes hurt, inconvenience, or damage to another, and the fact that the act done may otherwise be lawful shall not keep it from being a nuisance. The inconvenience complained of shall not be fanciful, or such as would affect only one of fastidious taste, but it shall be such as would affect an ordinary, reasonable man. State Law reference— Nuisance defined generally, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1. Owner means the holder of the title in fee simple and every mortgagee of record. Parties in interest means persons in possession of property and all individuals who have interest of record in the county where the property is located in a dwelling, building or structure, including executors, administrators, guardians and trustees. Public authority means any housing authority or any officer who is in charge of any department or branch of the government of the county or the state relating to health, fire, or building regulations or to other activities concerning dwellings, buildings or structures in the county. Public officer means the officers who are authorized by O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7—41-2-17 and appointed by the county. Repair means closing a dwelling, building or structure or the cleaning or removal of debris, trash or other materials present and accumulated which create a health or safety hazard in or about any dwelling, building or structure. (Res. of 1-8-92, § 1(C), (E)) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Secs. 14-28—14-40. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ABATEMENT OR REMOVAL
Sec. 14-41. - Procedure for enforcement of division. (a) Designation of public officer. A public officer shall be designated or appointed to exercise the powers prescribed by this article. Such appointment shall be made by the county commissioners. (b) Owners served with complaint; notice. Whenever a request is filed with the public officer by a public authority or by at least five residents of the unincorporated area of the county charging that any open well or pool is dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the public or that any dwelling, building or structure is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use or whenever it appears to the public officer, on his own motion, that any dwelling, building or structure is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use or is vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with drug crimes, the public officer shall, if his preliminary investigation discloses a basis for such charges, issue and cause to be served upon the owner of and any parties with interest in such open well, pool, dwelling, building, or structure, a complaint stating the charges in that respect, containing a notice that hearing will be held before the public officer, and the place within the county in which the property is located therein, fixed not less than ten days and no more than 30 days after the serving of the complaint. (c) Owner's right to reply. The owners and any parties in interest shall be given the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person or otherwise and give testimony of the place and time fixed in the complaint. The rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity shall not be controlling in hearings before the public officer. (d) Order of abatement or closure. If after proper notice and hearing the public officer determines that the open well, pool, dwelling, building or structure under consideration is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial industrial and business use or is vacant, dilapidated and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes, or is dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the public, he shall state in writing his findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the owner thereof an order: (1) If the repair, alteration or improvement of the open well, pool, dwelling, building or structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the open well, pool, dwelling, building, or structure, the owner or parties in interest may within the time specified in the order repair, alter or improve such dwelling, building, or structure, so as to render it no longer a danger or detriment to the health, safety and welfare of the public or fit for human habitation or for current commercial, industrial or business use, or the owner or parties in interest may choose to vacate and close the dwelling, building, or structure as to human habitation. (2) If the repair, alteration or improvement of this open pool, well, dwelling, building or structure cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the open well, pool, dwelling, building or structure, the order may instruct the owner or parties in interest within a time specified in the order to remove or demolish such dwelling, building, or structure. In no event shall the board of commissioners of the county require the closing, filling in, removal or demolition of any open well, pool, dwelling, building or structure except upon a finding that the cost of repair, alteration or improvement thereof exceeds one-half the value such open well, pool, building or structure will have when repaired to satisfy the minimum requirements of this division. (e) Notice on failure to comply. If the owners or parties in interest fail to comply when ordered to vacate and close, cover, fill in, or demolish the open well, pool, dwelling, building, or structure to be repaired, altered or improved or to be vacated, closed, covered, filled in, or demolished, the public officer may cause to be posted directly beside or on the main entrance of any open well, pool, dwelling, building, or structure, so closed, covered or filled in, a placard with the following words: "This well, pool or building is dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the public, or unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial or business use; the use or occupation of this open well, pool, or building for human use or for commercial, industrial, or business is prohibited and unlawful." (f) Failure to comply; abatement by public officer. If the owner fails to comply with any order to cover, fill in, remove or demolish the open well, pool, dwelling, building, or structure, the public officer may cause such open well, pool, dwelling, building or structure to be closed, filled in, removed or demolished; provided, however, that the duties of the public officer shall not be exercised until the county commissioners have by a majority vote ordered the public officer to proceed. (g) Costs of abatement a lien on property. The amount of the cost of vacating, closing, covering, filling in or removal or demolition by a public officer shall be a lien against the real property upon which such costs were incurred. Such lien shall attach to the real property upon the payment of all costs of demolition by the county and the filing of an itemized statement of the total sum of the costs by the public officer in the office of the county clerk on a lien docket maintained by the clerk for such purposes. (h) Sale of materials from demolished structure. If a dwelling, building or structure is removed or demolished by the public officer, he shall sell the materials of such dwellings, buildings or structures and shall credit the proceeds of such sale against the costs of the removal or demolition. Any balance remaining shall be deposited in the superior court by the public officer, shall be secured in such manner as it may be directed by any such court and shall be dispersed by such court to the persons found to be entitled thereto by final order or decree of such court. (i) Collection of amount due on lien. The county may enforce the collection of any amount due on such lien for covering, filling in, removal or demolition of open well, pool, dwellings, buildings or structures in the following manner: (1) The owners or parties in interest shall be allowed to satisfy the amount due on such lien by paying to the county within 30 days after the perfection of the lien, a sum of money equal to 25 percent of the total amount due and by further paying to the county the remaining balance due on such lien, together with interest at a rate of seven percent per annum, in three equal annual payments, each of which shall become due and payable on the anniversary date of the initial payment made as described in this subsection. (2) Should the property upon which such lien is perfected be sold, transferred, or conveyed by the owner or parties at interest at any time prior to the termination of the three-year period, then the entire balance due on such lien shall be due and payable to the county. (3) Should the amount due on such lien or any portion thereof be unpaid after the passage of the three-year period or upon the occurrence of the contingency provided for in subsection (i)(2) of this section, the county may enforce the collection of any amount due on such land for alteration, covering, filling in, repair or removal, or demolition of any open well, pool, dwellings, buildings or structures in the same manner as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-358 and other applicable state statutes. This procedure shall be subject to the right of redemption by any person having any right, title or interest in or lien upon the property. (Res. of 1-8-92, § 2) Sec. 14-42. - Determination by public officer that structure is unfit or vacant and used in connection with drug crimes. (a) The public officer appointed by the county commissioners may determine that a dwelling, building, or structure is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial or business use if he finds that conditions exist in such dwelling, building, or structure which are dangerous or injurious to the structure or the occupants of neighborhood dwellings, buildings or structures or of other residences of such county. Such conditions may include the following, without limiting the generality of the foregoing: (1) Defects therein increasing the hazards of fire, accidents or other calamities. (2) Lack of adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities. (3) Dilapidation. (4) Disrepair. (5) Structural defects. (6) Uncleanliness. (b) The public officer appointed by the county commissioners may determine that a dwelling, building or structure is vacant, dilapidated and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes upon personal observation or report of a law enforcement agency and evidence of drug crimes being committed. (Res. of 1-8-92, § 3) Sec. 14-43. - Powers of public officers. The county board of commissioners hereby authorizes the appointed public officer to exercise the following powers: (1) Investigate in the unincorporated areas of the county in order to determine which open wells, pools, dwellings, buildings or structures therein are dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare of the public or unfit for human habitation or unfit for current commercial, industrial or business use or are vacant, dilapidated and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes. (2) Administer oaths and affirmations, examine witnesses, and receive evidence. (3) Enter upon the premises for the purpose of making examinations; provided, however, that such entry shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession. (4) Appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents, and employees as he deems necessary to carry out the purposes of this article. (5) Delegate any of his functions and powers under this section to any such officer and agents as he may designate. (Res. of 1-8-92, § 4) Sec. 14-44. - Service of complaints or orders upon parties in interest and owners. (a) Complaints or orders issued by a public officer pursuant to this division shall in all cases be served upon each person in possession of the property, each owner, and each party in interest. The return of service signed by the public officer or his agent or an affidavit of service executed by any citizen of this state, reciting that a copy of such complaint or orders was served upon each person in possession of such property, each owner, and each party in interest personally or by leaving such copy at the place of his residence shall be sufficient evidence as to service of such person in possession, owner and party in interest. (b) If any of the owners and parties shall reside out of the county, service shall be perfected by enclosing a copy of such complaint or orders to be served upon such party or parties by the sheriff or any lawful deputy of the county of the residence of such party or parties or such service be made by any citizen; and the return of such sheriff or lawful deputy or the affidavit of such citizen of such party or parties were served either personally or by leaving a copy of the complaint or orders at the residence shall be conclusive as to such service. (c) Nonresidents of this state shall be served by publishing notice once each week for two successive weeks in the McDuffie Progress. (d) If either the owner or any party in interest is a minor or an insane person or person laboring under any disability, the guardian or other personal representative of such person shall be served, and if such guardian or personal representative of such person resides outside the county, he shall be served as provided for in subsection (c) of this section concerning service on nonresidents. (e) If the whereabouts of any owner or party in interest are unknown and the whereabouts cannot be ascertained by the public officer through the exercise of reasonable diligence, and the public officer shall make an affidavit to that effect, then the service of such complaint or order upon such person shall be made in the manner as provided for service upon a nonresident. (f) A copy of such complaint or order shall also be filed in the office of the clerk of the county superior court and listed in the lis pendens book located in the superior court clerk's office. The lis pendens notice shall contain a statement to the effect that a lien may arise against the described property and that an itemized statement of such lien is maintained on a lien docket maintained by the clerk of the county superior court. (Res. of 1-8-92, § 5) Sec. 14-45. - Injunctions against order to demolish, cover or fill in. Any person affected by an order issued by the public officer may petition to the superior court for an injunction restraining the public officer from carrying out the provisions of the order. The court may, upon such petition, issue a temporary injunction restraining the public officer pending the final dispossession of the cause; provided, however, that such person shall present such petition to the court within 15 days of the posting and service of the order of the public officer. De novo hearing shall be had by the court on petitions within 20 days. The court shall hear and determine the issues raised and shall enter such final order decree as law and justice may require; provided, however, that it shall not be necessary to file bond in any amount before obtaining a temporary injunction. (Res. of 1-8-92, § 6) Sec. 14-46. - Taking of property by eminent domain. Nothing in this division shall be construed as preventing the owner of any property from receiving just compensation for the taking of such property by the power of eminent domain under the laws of the state nor as permitting any property to be condemned or destroyed except in accordance with any police power of this state. (Res. of 1-8-92, § 7) Secs. 14-47—14-65. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FLOW-RATE RESTRICTIONS ON PLUMBING FIXTURES[3]
