Sec. 14-66. - Restrictions enumerated; deadline. (a) On or after July 1, 1991, no construction may be initiated within the county for any residential building of any type which: (1) Employs a gravity tank-type, flushometer-valve, or flushometer-tank toilet that uses more than an average of 1.6 gallons of water per flush; provided, however, this subsection shall not be applicable to one-piece toilets until July 1, 1992; (2) Employs a shower head that allows a flow of more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure; (3) Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of 1.0 gallons of water per flush; (4) Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.0 gallons of water per minute; or (5) Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.5 gallons of water per minute. (b) On or after July 1, 1992, there shall be no construction of any commercial building initiated within the county for any commercial building of any type which does not meet the requirements of subsections (a)(1) through (5) of this section. (Res. of 5-1-91) ARTICLE IV. - BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION
Sec. 14-70. - Code is remedial. The provisions of this chapter are hereby declared to be remedial, and shall be construed to secure the beneficial interests and purposes thereof, which are public safety, health and general welfare, through structural strength, stability, sanitation, adequate light and ventilation, and safety to life and property from fire and other hazards incident to the construction, alteration, repair, removal, demolition, use and occupancy of buildings, or structures. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-71. - Scope. (a) The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the installation of electrical, mechanical and plumbing systems and to the construction, alteration, repair, equipment use and occupancy, location, maintenance, removal and demolition, of every building or structure or any appurtenances connected or attached to such buildings, structures, or premises. (b) The provisions of this chapter shall not be held to deprive any federal or state agency, or any applicable governing body having jurisdiction, of any power or authority which it had on the effective date of this act or of any remedy then existing for the enforcement of its orders, nor shall it deprive any individual or corporation of its legal rights as provided by law. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-72. - Existing buildings. (a) If, within any twelve month period, alterations or repairs costing in excess of 50 percent of the then physical value of the building are made to an existing building, such building shall be made to conform to the requirements of this chapter for new buildings. (b) If an existing building is damaged by fire or otherwise in excess of 50 percent of its then physical value before such damage is repaired, it shall be made to conform to the requirements of this Code for new buildings. (c) If the cost of such alterations or repairs within any twelve month period or the amount of such damage as referred to in paragraph (b) is more than 25 but not more that 50 percent of the then physical value of the building, the portions to be altered or repaired shall be made to conform to the requirements of this chapter for new buildings to such extent as the department director may determine. (d) For the purpose of this section, physical value of the building shall be determined by the McDuffie County Tax Assessor's Office. (e) If the occupancy of an existing building is entirely changed, the building shall be made to conform to the requirements of this chapter for the new occupancy. If the occupancy of the only portion of an existing building is changed and that portion is separated from the remainder of the building, then only such portion need be made to conform. (f) Repairs and alterations, not covered by the preceding paragraphs of this section, restoring a building to its condition previous to damage or deterioration, or altering it in conformity with the provisions of this chapter or in such manner as will not extend or increase an existing nonconformity or hazard, may be made with the same kind of materials as those of which the building is constructed. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-73. - Installation or maintenance by homeowner. Nothing in this chapter shall prevent a homeowner from installing electrical, mechanical or plumbing systems or maintaining his home within his own property boundaries, provided such work is done by himself and is used exclusively by him or his family. Such privilege does not convey the right to violate any of the provision of this chapter, nor is it construed as exempting any such property owner from obtaining a permit, paying required fees and obtaining inspections. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-74. - Special historic building and districts. The provisions of this chapter relating to the construction, alteration, repair, enlargement, restoration, relocation or moving of buildings or structures shall not be mandatory for existing building or structures identified and classified by the state or local jurisdiction as historic buildings when such building or structures are judged by the department director to be safe and in the public interest of health, safety and welfare. The applicant shall submit any plans and specifications as may be required by the planning commission. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-75. - Maintenance. All buildings and structures, both existing and new, and all parts thereof, shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition. All devices or safeguards which are required by this chapter in a building erected, altered or repaired, shall be maintained in good working order. The owner, or his designated agent, shall be responsible for the maintenance of buildings and structures. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-76. - Department director. There is hereby established a department to be called the "planning commission" and the person in charge thereof shall be known as its "director". (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-77. - Inspectors. The director, with the approval of the Board of Commissioners, McDuffie County, Georgia, may appoint such number of officers, inspectors, assistants and other employees as shall be authorized from time to time. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-78. - Restrictions on employees. An officer or employee connected with the department, except one whose only connection is as a member of a board, established by this chapter, shall not be financially interested in the furnishing of labor, material or appliances for the construction alteration or maintenance of a building, unless he is the owner of such building. Such officer or employee shall not engage in any work which is inconsistent with his duties or with the interests of the department. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-79. - Records. The director shall keep, or cause to be kept, a record of the business of the department. The records of the department shall be open to public inspection. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-80. - Right of entry. The director shall enforce the provisions of this chapter, and he or his duty authorized representative, may enter any building, structure or premises to perform any duty imposed upon him by this chapter. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-81. - Stop work orders. Upon notice from the inspector, work on any building or structure that is being performed contrary to the provisions of this chapter or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, shall be immediately stopped. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, or to his agent, or to the person doing the work, or posted in a prominent place on the work site, and shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. Where an emergency exists, written notice shall not be required to be given by the inspector. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-82. - Revocation of permits. The director may revoke a permit or approval issued under the provisions of this chapter, in case there has been any false statement or misrepresentation as to a material fact in the application or plans on which the permit or approval was based or the failure to comply with any requirement upon which a permit is issued or used. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-83. - Unsafe buildings. All buildings or structures which are unsafe, unsanitary, or not provided with adequate egress, or which constitute a fire hazard, or are otherwise dangerous to human life, or which in relation to existing use constitute a hazard to safety or health by reason of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, obsolescence or abandonment, are unsafe buildings. All such buildings may be declared illegal and shall be abated by repair and rehabilitation or by demolition in accordance with the provisions of the standard unsafe building abatement codes. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-84. - Requirements not covered by specific provisions. Any requirement necessary for the strength or stability of an existing or proposed building or structure, or for the safety or health of the occupants thereof, not specifically covered by this chapter, shall be determined by the director. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-85. - Alternate materials and alternate methods of construction. The provisions of this chapter are not intended to prevent the use of any material or method of construction not specifically prescribed by this chapter, provided any such alternate has been approved and its use authorized by the director. The director shall approve any such alternate, provided he finds that the proposed design is satisfactory and at least the equivalent in quality, strength, effectiveness, fire-resistance, durability and safety. The director shall require that sufficient evidence or proof be submitted to substantiate any claim that may be made regarding its use. If, in the opinion of the director, the evidence and proof are not sufficient to justify approval, the applicant may refer the entire matter to the appropriate board as provided for by section 14-92. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-86. - Liability. Any officer or employee or member of a board charged with the enforcement of this Code, acting for the governing body in the discharge of his duties, shall not thereby render himself liable personally, and he is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties. Any suit brought against any officer or employee because of such act performed by him in the enforcement of any provision of this Code shall be defended by the county attorney until the final termination of the proceedings. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-87. - Permits. (a) When required. (1) Any owner, authorized agent or contractor who desires to construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, demolish or change the occupancy of a building or structure, or to erect or construct a sign of any description, or to install or alter fire-extinguishing apparatus or to install a steam boiler, furnace, heater, incinerator or other heat producing apparatus, or electrical, plumbing and mechanical systems, the installation of which is regulated by this chapter, or to cause any work to be done, shall first make application to the director and obtain the required permit. (2) A general permit shall carry with it the right to install in any building or part thereof, heating apparatus, sprinklers, elevators, sidewalk elevators, vaults, chutes, coal holes, lifts, cranes, derrick, steam power boilers, steam, oil, gas or vapor engines, provided the same are shown on the drawings and set forth in the specifications filed with the application for the permit; but where these are not shown in the drawings and covered by the specifications submitted with said application, special permits may be required. (3) Ordinary minor repairs may be made with the approval of the director without a permit, provided that such repairs shall not violate any of the provisions of this chapter. (4) No building permit shall be issued for and no building or other structure shall be erected on any lot within the county unless the street giving access to the lot upon which said building is proposed to be placed shall be accepted or opened as, or shall otherwise receive the legal status of a public street prior to that time, or unless such street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a subdivision plat approved by the planning commission, or on a street plat made and adopted by said planning commission or with a street located and accepted by the governing authority of the county or on an existing street as shown on a subdivision plat recorded prior to the adoption of this Code. (b) Form. Each application for a permit with the required fees, shall be filed with the director, on a form furnished for the purpose, and shall contain a general description of the proposed work, its location, the proposed occupancy of all parts of the building and such other information as may be required by the director. (c) Drawings and specifications. (1) When required by the director, two or more copies of specifications, and of drawings drawn to scale with sufficient clarity and detail to indicate the nature and character of the work, shall accompany every application. Such drawings and specifications, shall contain information, in the form of notes or otherwise, as to the quality of materials, where quality is essential to conformity with this chapter. Such information shall be as specific as required, and this Code shall not be cited as a whole or in part, nor shall the term "illegal" or its equivalent be used, as a substitute for specific information. (2) The director may require details, computations, and other data necessary to describe the construction and basis of calculations and they shall bear the signature of the person responsible for the design. (3) All drawings, specifications, and accompanying data shall bear the name and address of the designer. In the case of buildings or structures of Group E—Educational, Group I—Institutional and Group A—Assembly Occupancy, and all buildings or structures three stories or more in height or 5000 square feet in area, except one-and two-family dwellings, such designer shall be an architect or engineer legally registered under the laws of this state regulating the practice of architecture or engineering and shall affix his official seal to said drawing, specifications and accompanying data. (4) Plans for buildings and structures that require approval of the state fire marshal, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 25-2-13 must have same affixed. (5) Along with the application and plans each applicant shall, if required, submit proof acceptable to the director of compliance with the "Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Ordinances of McDuffie County, Georgia: and "The Storm-Water Management Regulation of McDuffie County, Georgia". (6) If sewage disposal is to be by any means other than central or public sewage system, then, a waster disposal permit shall be required. (7) Along with the application, each applicant shall submit proof acceptable to the director of compliance with the Land Subdivision Regulations of McDuffie County and proof acceptable to the director of the compliance with the requirement of section 74-31(C) of the Land Subdivision Regulation of McDuffie County and section 14-87A.4., of the Building and Construction Code of McDuffie County. (d) If required, a recordable plat must be approved by the planning commission in order to obtain a building permit and/or mobile home permit. Any request for a waiver of this requirement shall be considered a request for variance from the planning commission board. (e) Examination of drawings. (1) The director shall examine or cause to be examined each application for permit and the drawings and computations filed therewith and shall ascertain by such examinations whether the construction indicated and described is in accordance with the requirements of this chapter and all other pertinent laws or ordinances. (2) The director may accept a sworn affidavit from a registered architect or engineer stating that the plans submitted conform to the laws as to egress, type of construction and general arrangement and, if accompanied by drawings showing the structural design and by a statement that the plans and design conform to the requirements of this chapter as to strength, stresses, strains, loads and stability, he may without any examination or inspection accept such affidavit, provided that the architect or engineer who made such an affidavit agrees to submit to the director, on the completion of the structure, a certification that the structure has been erected in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. Where the director relies upon such affidavit, the architect or engineer shall assume full responsibility for the compliance with all provisions of this chapter and other pertinent laws or ordinances. (f) Action on application. (1) A person, firm or corporation shall not erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve, remove, convert or demolish any building or structure or cause the same to be done, without first obtaining a separate building permit for such building or structure from the director. (2) If the director is satisfied that the work described in an application for the permit and the drawings filed therewith conform to the requirements of this chapter and other pertinent laws and ordinances, he shall issue a permit therefor to the applicant. (3) If the application for a permit and the drawings filed therewith describe work which does not conform to the requirements of this chapter or other pertinent laws or ordinances, the director shall not issue a permit. Such refusal may be verbal or in writing and shall contain the reasons therefor. (g) Conditions of the permit. The director shall act upon an application for a permit with plans filed, or as amended, without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. A permit issued shall be construed to be a license to proceed with the work and shall not be construed to be a license to violate, cancel, alter or set aside any of the provisions of this chapter, nor shall such issuance of a permit prevent the director from thereafter withdrawing such permit, or requiring a correction of errors in plans or in construction, or of violations of this chapter. Every permit issued shall become invalid unless the work authorized by such permit is commenced within six months after its issuance, or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of six months after the time the work is commenced; provided, that, for cause one or more extensions of time, for periods not exceeding 90 days each, may be allowed, and such requests for extensions shall be in writing to the director. (h) Permits issued upon affidavits. Whenever a permit is to be issued in reliance upon an affidavit or whenever the work to be covered by a permit involved construction under conditions which, in the opinion of the director, are hazardous or complex, the director may require that the architect or engineer who signed the affidavit or made the drawings or computations shall be required to supervise such work, be responsible for its conformity with the approved drawings, and forthwith upon its completion, make and file with the director written affidavit that the work has been done in conformity with the approved plan and with the structural provisions of the Code. In the event such architect or engineer is not available, the owner shall employ in his stead a competent person or agency whose qualifications are approved by the director. (i) Foundation permits. When application for permit to erect or enlarge a building has been filed and pending issuance of such permit, the director, may at his own discretion, issue a special permit for the foundation of such building. The holder of such a special permit shall proceed at his own risk and without assurance that a permit for the superstructure will be granted. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-88. - Fees. (a) General. A permit shall not be issued until the fees prescribed in this section shall have been paid. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-89 - Building permit violations. If the director determines that the valuation of the building, alteration or structure appears to be underestimated on the application, permit shall be denied, unless the applicant can show detailed estimated cost to meet the approval of the director. Permit violations shall include total cost, such as plumbing, electrical, mechanical equipment and other systems. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-90. - Inspections. (a) General (1) Before issuing a permit, the director may examine or cause to be examined any building for which an application has been received for permit to enlarge, alter, repair, move, demolish or change the occupancy thereof. He shall inspect all buildings and structures, from time to time, during and upon completion of the work for which a permit was issued. He shall make a record of such examination and inspection and of all violations of this chapter. (2) When deemed necessary by the director, he shall make an inspection of materials or assemblies at the point of manufacture of fabrication. He shall make a record of every such examination and inspection and of all violations of this chapter. (3) The director may make, or cause to be made, the inspections required by this section. (b) Inspections required. (1) The director shall inspect or cause to be inspected at various intervals all construction or work for which a permit is required, and a final inspection shall be made of every building or structure upon completion. (2) Work requiring a building permit shall not be commenced until the permit holder or his agent shall have posted the building permit card in a conspicuous place on the front of the premises. (3) The inspector upon notification from the permit holder or his agent shall make the following inspections of buildings and such other inspection as may be necessary, and shall either approve that portion of the construction as completed or shall notify the permit holder or his agent when work fails to comply with the Code: a. Foundation—Footing and setbacks. b. Concrete slab—Plumbing. c. Rough-in—Electrical, plumbing, mechanical, energy. d. Framing. e. Fireplace. f. Final—electrical, energy. (4) Work shall not be done on any part of a building or structure beyond the point indicated in each successive inspection without first obtaining the written approval of the inspector. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-91. - Rules and regulations. The planning commission board shall adopt such reasonable rules and regulations as are necessary for the conduct of its affairs and shall, when needing legal advise, consult with the county attorney, through the director. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-92. - Hearings. Any party aggrieved or dissatisfied by the decision of any inspector or other official of McDuffie County shall have the right to appear before the planning commission board charged herein with the responsibility of interpreting the Code in question. The decision of the planning commission board shall be final unless the dissatisfied party appeals to the county commission within 30 days from the date of such decision. Such appeal shall set forth in detail and with specificity the grounds thereof and shall be filed, in writing, with the building director. The chairman of the planning commission board from which such appeal is taken shall transmit to the building director all pertinent evidence. The building director shall cause said appeal to be placed on the agenda at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the county commission. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-93. - State license. Effective July 1, 2004, McDuffie County will not issue or allow any electrical, mechanical (conditioned air), or plumbing permit unless the applicant shows proof of a valid state license as required by O.C.G.A. § 43-14-8. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-94. - Enforcement. (a) Any person who violates any provision of this chapter or fails to comply with the requirements thereof shall, upon conviction, be fined not more than $1,000.00 or imprisoned in the county jail for not more than 60 days, or both, and in addition shall pay the costs of such action. Each day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. The owner or tenant of building, structure, premises or part thereof, any architect, builder, contractor, agent or other person who commits, participates in, assists in, or maintains such violation may each be found guilty of a separate offense and suffer penalties herein provided. (b) In addition to the foregoing, it shall be the duty of the director to enforce the provisions of this chapter, including, but not being limited to, the right to refuse to issue, approve, sanction, or certify any permit, license or certificate. In addition thereto, in the event any building, structure, or other construction and improvements or work, subject to the provisions of this chapter, is or is proposed to be erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, converted, maintained, done or any building, structure or work is or is proposed to be done or used in violation of this chapter, the director, board of commissioners, or county attorney or any adjacent or neighboring property owner who would be specially damaged by such violation, in addition to other remedies, may institute injunction, mandamus or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance of use; or to correct or abate such violation, or to prevent the occupancy of said building, structure or other construction and improvement. (Ord. of 5-21-02) Sec. 14-95. - Other provisions of this Code. Nothing contained in this chapter shall abrogate, modify, alter or change the requirements of any other chapter of the Code. (Ord. of 5-21-02)

div.head: Chapter 18 - BUSINESSES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 34; health and sanitation, ch. 38; signs, ch. 62; solid waste, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; taxation, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 82. State Law reference— County's authority to levy, assess and collect business and occupational license taxes and license fees; exemptions, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-22.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 18-1—18-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TRANSIENT MEAT PRODUCT MERCHANTS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Health and sanitation, ch. 38. State Law reference— Sale of dog meat for human consumption prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-160.
Sec. 18-26. - Provisions saved from repeal. The provisions of the resolution of March 5, 1977, relating to the licensing of transient meat product merchants are not repealed and shall continue in full force and effect pending a revision of the subject matter by the county. Secs. 18-27—18-45. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - HOTELS, MOTELS AND LODGINGS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— County and municipal excise taxes on rooms, lodgings and accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq.; operators of hotels, inns and roadhouses, O.C.G.A. § 43-21-1 et seq.; tourist courts, O.C.G.A. § 31-28-1 et seq.
Sec. 18-46. - License required. Any person or entity operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished for value within the county shall, by January 31 of each year, purchase and maintain a business license for such operation. The fee for such annual license shall be $1.00. Such license shall be displayed in an open manner. (Res. of 4-1-87(2)) Secs. 18-47—18-65. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - TIMBER AND PULPWOOD HARVESTING[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Editor's note—An ordinance adopted April 2, 2003, repealed ch. 18, art. IV, §§ 18-66, 18-67, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, art. IV, pertained to timber harvesting and derived from Ord. adopted Nov. 17, 1992, §§ 1, 2.
Sec. 18-66. - Surety bond (letter of credit) and permit required; repair of roadway, ditches and bridges. (a) This article shall be applicable to all persons or firms harvesting standing timber in any unincorporated area of McDuffie County for delivery as pulpwood, logs, poles, posts or wood chips to any wood yard or processing plant located inside or outside this state. (b) Any person or firm set out in section (a) above, shall provide an application for a permit for such harvesting operations to the director of the McDuffie County Public Works Department using Georgia Forestry Commission Form 12-6-24 prior to cutting any such timber as follows: (1) Prior written application shall be required of any person or firm harvesting such timber for each separate tract to be harvested thereby, shall be in such form as prescribed by rule or regulation of the director, and shall consist of the information required by the application form referenced above as well as the following: a. A map of the area which identifies the location of the tract to be harvested and, as to those trucks which will be traveling to and from such tract for purposes of picking up and hauling loads of cut forest products, the main point of ingress to such tract from a public road and, if different, the main point of egress from such tract to a public road; b. A statement as to whether the timber will be removed pursuant to a lump-sum sale, per-unit sale, or owner harvest for purposes of ad valorem taxation under O.C.G.A. § 48-5-7.5 or other applicable laws; c. The name, address, and daytime telephone number of the timber seller if the harvest is pursuant to a lump-sum or per-unit sale or of the timber owner if the harvest is an owner harvest; d. The name, business address, business telephone number, and nighttime or emergency telephone number of the person or firm harvesting such timber. (2) Prior to operations and prior to issuing any permit the county public works department shall inspect the point of access to county roads and determine suitability. If a culvert is deemed necessary, it shall be no shorter than 40 feet and installed by the permit owner. If a culvert has been deemed necessary, no harvesting operation shall occur until the public works department has inspected the installation of the culvert and approved it. (3) After issuance of the permit, the harvester shall: a. Post a copy of the permit on the site which must be visible from the county road at the point of access. b. Signs shall be installed stating, "TRUCKS ENTERING HIGHWAY" and/or "LOGGING OPERATION AHEAD" and are to be placed 750 feet in both directions of each county road access point. Signs shall be 36 inches x 36 inches, erected in a diamond shape, orange in color with black legend. (D.O.T. specs) (c) The persons or firms subject to such application requirement must deliver a bond or letter of credit as provided by this section. Any permit shall not be or remain affective for such harvesting operations unless and until the person or firm providing such application has delivered to the governing authority or its designated agent a valid surety bond, executed by a surety corporation authorized to transact business in this state, protecting the county against any damage caused by such person or firm in the amount of $5,000.00 or, at the option of the person or firm harvesting, a valid irrevocable letter of credit issued by a bank or savings and loan association, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 7-1-4, in the amount of and in lieu of such bond. (d) No permit shall be effective until approved by county public works department in compliance with the requirements of subsections (b) and (c), and the permit shall be effective only for a period of 180 days from approval. (e) During operations, the following is required: (1) All harvesting shall be conducted on permitted site and off county roads and right-of-way. Logging and skidding on county roads and right-of-way is strictly prohibited. (2) Ditches shall be kept clear of all debris and residue to allow for proper drainage. (3) There shall be no blockage of county roads at the access site and roads must remain open at all times. (4) No equipment, trucks or trailers shall be allowed to park on any public road or right-of-way. (5) Mud or debris shall not be carried onto paved roads by logging vehicles, and if deemed necessary by county authorities, temporary gravel exits shall be constructed at the permit owner's expense. (6) During rain or inclement weather, logging vehicles shall not be operated over the county's unimproved roads when such travel will cause damage to the road system or impede traffic flow. (f) Upon written notice (except in case of emergency) from the issuing authority, work shall be stopped if the conditions are not in compliance with the ordinance. The harvester shall correct the violations within five days of the notice, otherwise the public works department will make repairs and deduct the cost from the bond or letter of credit. (g) Completion/release of bond. The operator shall notify public works department of completion of operations. The department will then inspect the site to insure the area has been restored to original condition. The operator will be notified in writing of any deficiencies and given 15 days to correct them. (1) The surety bond or letter of credit required herein shall be used by McDuffie County to insure that any damage caused by the harvesting operation, including, without limitations, those as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1, shall be properly repaired. All damages as contemplated herein shall be properly taken care of by the person or firm harvesting such timber and then the bond shall be released. (2) No bond shall be released until such time as all such damages have been corrected by the person or firm doing the harvesting operations. Should they fail to do so, the county is authorized to make any necessary repairs at the expense of the person or firm doing such harvesting and to call upon the bond or letter of credit to satisfy the cost of such repair. Should the cost of the repair exceed the bond, then the person or firm harvesting the timber as contemplated herein shall be responsible for any excess costs thereof. (Ord. of 10-21-03; Res. of 10-5-05; Res. of 1-13-10; Res. of 4-7-10) Editor's note— Ord. of Oct. 21, 2003, repealed § 18-66, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 18-66 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. of April 2, 2003. Sec. 18-67. - Penalty. Failure of any harvester to comply with any of the provisions of this article, upon conviction of a violation, shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-13; however, the minimum fine which may be imposed shall not be less than $250.00. Each day this article is violated shall be deemed a separate offense and shall be punished as such. (Ord. of 4-2-03) Secs. 18-68—18-90. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - FORTUNETELLING[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- State Law reference— County governing authority may prohibit, regulate or tax the practice of fortunetelling, astrology and palmistry, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-15.
Sec. 18-91. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Fortunetelling means any foretelling of any event or events which may occur in the future by means of cards, palmistry, astrology, crystal gazing, numerology, phrenology, clairvoyance, necromancy, magic or by any supernatural, mystic or occult means; or in locating or divining any treasure, mineral, lost or missing article or person by such means; or in persuading, inducing or procuring any person to transfer, convey, donate, devise, bequeath, pledge, mortgage or deposit any money or property by such means; or to describe, expound or resolve any matter pertaining to business finance, romance, bereavement, or good or bad fortune, by such means; or pretending, assuming or undertaking to do any of the abovementioned things or to aid or assist any other person in so doing; or to make, sell or give away charms, potions, talismans or magic articles, or anything purporting to be such. Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 18-92. - License—Required. No person shall practice or engage in fortunetelling, either for or without compensation, or attempt to do so or hold themselves out or advertise that they practice or engage in fortunetelling without first obtaining a license. Sec. 18-93. - Same—Fee. The nonrefundable license fee payable at the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners at the time the fortunetelling license application is submitted shall be $500.00 annually. (Mo. of 2-19-91) Secs. 18-94—18-100. - Reserved. ART. VI. - ARCADES PERMIT
Sec. 18-101. - Definitions. Arcade. A location where three or more bona fide coin-operated amusement machines are operated. Bona fide coin-operated amusement machine means the same as this term is defined in O.C.G.A § 48-17-1(2) and any applicable state regulations. License means a license issued by the county to operate an arcade. Location means a business in the county which has or proposes to have a coin-operated amusement machine. Person or persons means any individual, corporation plus officers and director, or partners. (Ord. of 7-18-00, § 1; Res. of 9-19-00, § 1) Sec. 18-102. - Distance requirements—Plat required. Every application for an arcade in the county shall be verified by a plat prepared by a licensed state surveyor or civil engineer, showing the distance for the proposed business, as hereafter provided. (1) No license for the operation of an arcade shall be issued for any location: a. Within 1,250 feet of the property line of a private residential dwelling; b. Within 1,250 feet of the property line of any public library or branch of any public library. c. Within 1,250 feet from the property line of any church, shrine, chapel of a mortuary or other place used exclusively for religious purposes; d. Within 1,250 feet of the property line of any school or college campus. The schools and colleges referred to herein shall include such public, private, or church-supported schools which teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of this state; e. Within 1,250 feet of a regular stop where a school bus for the transportation of school children in the public schools of the county shall board or discharge passengers; f. Within 1,250 feet of any other zoning classification use regulated under comprehensive zoning ordinance of the county; or g. Where the proposed location is one and one-half miles or less from an existing location for which the county commission has issued an arcade license. (2) The distance requirements set out above shall apply in any and all directions from the property lines of the proposed location, as measured in a straight line. The plat shall accompany and be made a part of the application for such license. (3) In determining whether or not a license applied for hereunder shall be granted, renewed, transferred or issued to a new location, in addition to all the provisions of this section, the following shall be considered in the public interest and welfare: a. Reputation, character. The applicant's reputation, character, trade and business associates or past business ventures, mental and physical capacity to conduct this business. b. Previous violations of county code. If the applicant is a previous holder of an arcade license, whether or not he has violated any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business. c. Manner of conducting prior arcade business. If the applicant is a previous holder of an arcade license, the manner in which he conducted the business thereunder, especially as to the necessity for unusual police observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business. d. Location. The location for which the license is sought, as to traffic congestion, general character of neighborhood, and the effect such an establishment would have on the adjacent and surrounding property values. e. Number of licenses in trading area. The number of licenses already granted for similar business in the trading area of the place for which the license is sought. f. Previous revocation of license. If the applicant is a person and/or other entity whose license issued under public powers of any governing authority has been previously suspended or revoked or who has previously had an arcade license suspended or revoked. g. Payment of taxes and other charges. If the applicant and business are not delinquent in the payment of any local taxes or other fees or charges. h. Congregation of minors. Any circumstances which may cause minors to congregate in the vicinity of the proposed location even if the location meets the distance requirement under section 18-102(2) herein above. i. Prior incidents. Evidence that a substantial number of incidents requiring police intervention have occurred within the immediate area during the 12 months immediately preceding the date of application. j. Previous denial or revocation. The denial of an application, or the revocation of a license, occurring within the preceding 12 months, which was based on the qualifications of the proposed location. k. Renewal. 1. All licenses granted hereunder are privilege licenses and shall expire on December 31 of each year. Licensees who desire to renew their licenses shall file an application therefor, together with the requisite fee with the clerk of the county commissioners for such renewal, upon forms approved by the clerk of the county commissioners, on or before December 1 of each year. 2. All licenses to be renewed for the subsequent calendar year shall be submitted by the clerk of the county commissioners to the commission for approval no later than December 15 of each year. Any licenses that have been placed on probation, suspension or have been revoked by the commission during the year shall be submitted on a separate list by the clerk of the county commissioners for review and consideration for approval. 3. No license may be transferred to any other location. 4. Any business with coin-operated amusement machines prior to the original adoption date of this article, September 19, 2000, who otherwise would have to comply with its provisions shall obtain a conditional license for that location without having to comply with the distance provisions of this article. This conditional license must be renewed every year as required by this article but shall automatically expire without the right of renewal whenever the current owner or operator ceases to operate the present location, increases the number of coin-operated amusement machines, or changes the type of machines currently in their business. (Ord. of 7-18-00, § 1; Res. of 9-19-00, §§ 2, 3, 7) Sec. 18-103. - Individuals not eligible for license. The following are not eligible for an arcade license: (1) A person or persons who have been convicted of a felony in any jurisdiction. A conviction, for purposes of this paragraph, includes a guilty plea or plea of nolo contendere. (2) A person or persons who have been convicted of a non-felonious crime of moral turpitude, lottery, or illegal possession and sale of narcotics or liquors within the five years preceding the filing of the applications. A conviction, for purposes of this paragraph, includes a guilty plea or a plea of nolo contendere. (3) A person whose license to operate an arcade has been revoked for cause in any state or territory of the United States within the ten years preceding the filing of the application. (4) A person who has knowingly falsified information or made any material misrepresentation on the application for the license under this article or any application under the predecessor ordinance for the county or the City of Thomson submitted within the ten years preceding the filing of the application. (5) Should any such applicant, partner or officer or director of any applicant entity, after a license has been granted, be convicted or plead guilty or nolo contendere to a crime involving moral turpitude, or to the violation of any laws of the state regulating gambling or the lottery laws, said license shall be subject after hearing to immediate suspension or revocation. (Ord. of 7-18-00, § 1) Sec. 18-104. - Proper zoning required. No license shall be issued for the operation of an arcade unless the license holder's place of business is located in an area zoned C-2. (Ord. of 7-18-00, § 1; Res. of 9-19-00, § 4) Sec. 18-105. - Application for license. All applicants for a license to operate an arcade shall give written notice of their intention to make such to the county clerk. (1) All applicants for licenses hereunder shall give notice that an application has been filed and of the purpose of making such application by publication of an advertisement once a week for four consecutive weeks prior to the date of consideration of the application by the county board of commissioners in the newspaper in which legal advertisements are published. The first advertisement shall not appear more than forty days prior to the date of such consideration. The advertisement shall be of type not smaller than ten point capital and lower case and shall be at least a one-inch column. The advertisement shall appear on the same days as legal advertisements are regularly published. (2) The notice shall contain a particular description of the location of the proposed business, the name of the applicant(s), the date, time and place of hearing, and a statement that any legal objections to the issuance must be made at or prior to the time of hearing, and, if prior to the time of hearing, must be in writing and received by the clerk of the board of commissioners on or before the date and time of hearing. (3) Applicants shall provide proof of such notice by providing the clerk, prior to the time of the hearing on license issuance, the affidavit of the publisher of the newspaper in which said notice was published, which affidavit shall reflect the content of the notice and the dates of publishing. (4) The applicant shall cause to be placed upon the location of the proposed business a sign or signs stating the following: McDuffie County Arcade License Applied For: A hearing before the McDuffie County Board of Commissioners shall be on the ____________ day of ____________, 20____________, at ____________:____________ o'clock (a.m./p.m.) in the Grand Jury Room at the McDuffie County Courthouse, 337 Main Street, Thomson, Georgia. All interested persons take notice. The sign or signs shall be at least 24 inches by inches in size containing lettering not less than two inches in height with said sign(s) facing toward all public streets, sidewalk, or other public property which adjoin or adjoins the location so as to be clearly visible by persons using such public area. The sign shall be posted on the property from the date of the first publication of the legal advertisement through the date of consideration by the county board of commissioners. (Ord. of 7-18-00, § 1; Res. of 9-19-00, § 5) Sec. 18-106. - Right of suspension by county. The county board of commissioners shall have the right to suspend any license issued under this article whenever a person, firm, or corporation doing business violates any law or ordinance of the United States, or the state or the county; or when it shall be determined by the board of commissioners that there is a violation of a nuisance law; or when the health, morals, interests and convenience of the public demand the suspension of such license. Any licensee whose license is suspended hereunder shall have a right to a hearing before the board of commissioners within 30 days of the suspension with the right to present evidence after which the license shall be suspended, placed on probation or permanently revoked, or otherwise it shall be restored and remain in full force. (Ord. of 7-18-00, § 1; Res. of 9-19-00, § 6) Sec. 18-107. - Cost of arcade license. The cost of the arcade license is $100.00 and must be submitted at the time that the application and other documentation is submitted to the local government officials. (Ord. of 7-18-00, § 1) Sec. 18-108. - Penalty for violation of article. All persons, firms or corporations failing to comply with the mandatory provisions of this article or doing any act prohibited in the article shall be guilty of an offense, and, upon trial as a misdemeanor and conviction, shall be as provided in §§ 1-13 and 1-14 of the county code. (Ord. of 7-18-00, § 1) Secs. 18-109—18-120. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - AMUSEMENT GAMES PERMIT
Sec. 18-121. - Definitions. Bona fide coin-operated amusement machines means the same as this term is defined in O.C.G.A § 48-17-1 (2). Location. A business in the county which has been issued a valid business tax certificate. Machine owner. Any person, firm or corporation which owns a bona fide coin-operated amusement machine. Permit. An amusement game permit issued pursuant to this article. (Ord. of 7-18-00, § 1) Sec. 18-122. - Amusement game permit required. Any machine owner who desires to place one or more bona fide coin-operated amusement machines in a location shall complete and mail a registration for amusement game permit accompanied by a $25.00 fee to the clerk of the board of commissioners of the county which shall issue a permit to the machine owner for that location. (Ord. of 7-18-00, § 1) Sec. 18-123. - Purpose of securing a permit. The purpose of securing a permit is to provide a record of machine owners who own bona fide coin-operated amusement machines and have placed those machines in a business in the county. (Ord. of 7-18-00, § 1) Sec. 18-124. - Failure to apply for permit. The failure of a machine owner to apply for a permit under this article shall result in a fine of $50.00. (Ord. of 7-18-00, § 1) Sec. 18-125. - Affect on machine owner's other statutory duties. This article applies independently from and has no affect on other statutory obligations of an amusement machine owner within this article. (Ord. of 7-18-00, § 1) Secs. 18-126—18-150. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - AMUSEMENT GAME ORDINANCE
Sec. 18-151. - Short title. This article shall be known as the "McDuffie County Amusement Game Ordinance". (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 1) Sec. 18-152. - Gambling devices prohibited. Gambling devices, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20(2), are hereafter prohibited in McDuffie County, and the ownership, use, or transport thereof shall be a misdemeanor pursuant to state law, except as exempted pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 16-12-35(a) through (k). (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 2) Sec. 18-153. - Gambling places prohibited. Gambling places, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20(3), are prohibited in the county, and the operation thereof shall be a misdemeanor pursuant to state law. (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 3) Sec. 18-154. - Definitions. The following word, terms, or phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Amusement game machines/coin-operated machines shall have the same meaning as "bona fide coin-operated amusement machine." Amusement game room means any location as provided in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(b), (c), or (d), where one or more bona fide coin-operated amusement machines are operated that permit noncash redemption as provided in O.C.G.A. §§ 16-12-35(d)(1)(B), (C), or a combination thereof. Board means the Board of Commissioners of McDuffie County. Bona fide coin-operated amusement machine(s) means the same as the term is defined in O.C.G.A. §§ 50-27-70(a)(2)(A) and (B) and any applicable regulations of the State of Georgia. Examples of bona fide coin-operated amusement machines include, but are not limited to, the following: (1) Pinball machines; (2) Console machines; (3) Video games; (4) Crane machines; (5) Claw machines; (6) Pusher machines; (7) Bowling machines; (8) Novelty arcade games; (9) Foosball or table soccer machines; (10) Miniature racetrack, football, or golf machines; (11) Target or shooting gallery machines; (12) Basketball machines; (13) Shuffleboard games; (14) Kiddie ride games; (15) Skee-Ball machines; (16) Air hockey machines; (17) Roll down machines; (18) Trivia machines; (19) Laser games; (20) Simulator games; (21) Virtual reality machines; (22) Maze games; (23) Racing games; (24) Coin-operated pool tables or coin-operated billiard tables as defined in paragraph (3) of [O.C.G.A.] § 43-8-1; and (25) Any other similar amusement machine which can be legally operated in Georgia. The term also means machines of any kind or character used by the public to provide music whose operation requires the payment of or the insertion of a coin, bill, other money, token, ticket, card, or similar object such as jukeboxes or other similar types of music machines. The term "bona fide coin-operated amusement machine" does not include the following: (1) Coin-operated washing machines or dryers; (2) Vending machines which for payment of money dispense products or services; (3) Gas and electric meters; (4) Pay telephones; (5) Pay toilets; (6) Cigarette vending machines; (7) Coin-operated scales; (8) Coin-operated gumball machines; (9) Coin-operated parking meters; (10) Coin-operated television sets which provide cable or network programming; (11) Coin-operated massage beds; and (12) Machines which are not legally permitted to be operated in Georgia. County means McDuffie County Georgia. Designee means the staff or department appointed by the board of commissioners to administer the provisions set forth herein. Location means a business within the county that has complied with the provisions of the ordinances relating to occupation taxes and business licenses and the entire office or area of the business in any one location owned or leased by the same proprietor(s) where the lessor(s) allow the space to be used for business purposes. Location also includes that area located within the property lines of the land in which the amusement game room business is located. Location owner or location operator means an owner or operator of a business where one or more bona fide coin-operated amusement machines are available for commercial use and play by the public, or shall have the same definition as found in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70. O.C.G.A. means the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 4) Sec. 18-155. - License required. No person, firm, or corporation shall engage in the business of an owner or operator of an amusement game room, as defined herein, without first having obtained an amusement game room license, and without having first paid the applicable occupation tax and obtained an occupational tax certificate as required by this article. A separate amusement game room license must be obtained, and separate occupational tax paid, for each location in the jurisdiction in which bona fide coin-operated amusement machines are operated. (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 5) Sec. 18-156. - Application for license. (a) An applicant for an amusement game room license must be at least 18 years of age. (b) A license will be issued only to a person who is a citizen of the United States or an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence in the United States. Where an applicant is other than a natural person, such applicant must be a person representing an entity organized and existing under the laws of the United States or one of its states. (c) Upon application, the applicant shall consent to a criminal background check and shall release the county, its elected officials, officers, agents, employees and representatives from any liability resulting from any criminal background check performed on the applicant. (d) No application shall be processed for any applicant convicted or pleading guilty or nolo contendere to any charge under any federal, state or local law, constituting a felony, within ten years prior to the date of the filing of the application for a license. (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 6) Sec. 18-157. - License application. A person desiring to obtain a license shall make application on the forms prescribed by the Planning Commission of McDuffie County. (1) The application form for a license shall require, but shall not be limited to, the following information: a. The name and address of the applicant. b. The name and location of the proposed amusement game room, and the name and address of the owner of the location in which the arcade is/will be located. c. A description of all of the amusement game machines, including the name, address and telephone number of the owner of each machine, and the registration number for each machine from the Georgia State Lottery Corporation decal on the amusement game machine. d. Certification from the county tax commissioner that all taxes then due to the county have been paid on the property where the amusement game room is or will be located. e. As required by the provision of subsection 18-156(c), all applicants shall furnish a background check through the office of the Sheriff of McDuffie County, and copy of the current McDuffie County Occupation Tax Certificate, and other material or information as may be required by the designee. Failure to furnish data required by the designee shall be deemed to be a withdrawal of the application. f. Each application for an initial license and renewal license shall provide the name and address of the master license issued by the Georgia Lottery Corporation to the owner of any amusement game machines located in the county as referenced in section 18-164. (2) Application fee(s) as prescribed by the county shall be due and payable upon application for the license. Failure to pay any license, administrative, or investigative fees at the time of filing the application, or failure to furnish all information as required, will cause the application to be deemed as incomplete and no further action will be taken until such application is complete as determined by the designee. (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 7) Sec. 18-158. - License review. When it has be determined by the designee that the initial application is complete, and applicable fees paid, the application shall be presented to the board of commissioners for review. Unless otherwise required or requested, no such board review shall be required for the annual renewal of an amusement game room license. (1) Applications shall be presented to the board of commissioners within 45 days after the date such application is deemed complete. The designee shall notify the applicant of the date and time that the application will be presented to the board of commissioners. Upon presentment to the board of commissioners, the board shall conduct a hearing at which time the applicant may appear and present any matters in support of the application, and, any other person may appear and present matters in support of, or in opposition to, the application. (2) In determining whether or not a license applied for hereunder shall be granted, the following shall be considered in the public interest and welfare: a. Reputation, character. The applicant's reputation, character, trade and business associates or past business ventures, mental, physical, and financial capacity to conduct the business. b. Previous violations of County Code. If the applicant is a previous holder of an amusement game room license, whether or not he/she has violated any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business. c. Manner of conducting prior amusement game room business. If the applicant is a previous holder of an arcade or amusement game room license, the manner in which he conducted the business, especially as to the necessity for unusual police observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business. d. Location. The location for which the license is sought, as to traffic congestion, general character of the neighborhood, and the effect such an establishment would have on the adjacent and surrounding residents or properties. e. Number of licenses in trading area. The number of licenses already granted for similar business in the trading area of the place for which the license is sought. f. Previous revocation of license. If the applicant is a person and/or other entity whose license issued under public powers of any governing authority has been previously suspended or revoked or who has previously had an arcade or amusement game room license suspended or revoked. g. Payment of taxes and other charges. If the applicant and business are delinquent in the payment of any local taxes, license, or other fees or charges. h. Congregation of minors. Any circumstances which may cause minors to congregate in the vicinity of the proposed location. i. Prior incidents. Evidence that a substantial number of incidents requiring police intervention which have occurred within the immediate area during the 12 months immediately preceding the date of application. j. Previous denial or revocation. The denial of an application, or the revocation of a license, occurring within the preceding 12 months, which was based on the qualifications of the proposed location. (3) Upon presentation of the report and any recommendations by the designee to the board of commissioners, the board shall take action denying, approving, conditionally approving, or it may defer action for a period not to exceed 61 days in order to obtain further information. If the application is denied the board of commissioners shall set forth the reasons for such denial. (4) In all instances in which an application is denied under the provisions of this article, the applicant may not reapply for a similar license for the same location for at least one year from the date of such denial or revocation. (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 8) Sec. 18-159. - License expiration and renewal. (a) Each license granted under the provisions of this article shall expire on December 31 of the calendar year for which the license was issued. Renewal applications shall be filed on or prior to December 31 of each year. A 20 percent late fee of the total fees due shall be assessed on renewal applications received after December 31. Applicants for renewal of a license shall pay the license fee at the time of the filing of the renewal application. (b) Failure to renew a license by February 1 shall subject the owner or operator to the issuance of a court citation to appear in the Magistrate Court of McDuffie County for violation of subsection 18-159(a). (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 9) Sec. 18-160. - Minimum distance requirements. (a) No amusement game room operated pursuant to a license issued under this article shall be located closer than: (1) One hundred yards of a church, shrine, chapel of a mortuary, or other place used exclusively for religious purposes; (2) Two hundred yards of any school or college campus including public, private, or church supported schools which teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of the state. Such separation shall not be applicable to private residence schooling commonly referred to as "home schooling". (3) Two hundred yards of a private residence. Restriction applicable only for amusement game rooms having more than three amusement game machines. (4) Two hundred yards of a public library or branch of any public library; (5) Two hundred yards of a regular school bus stop for the transportation of school children in the public or private schools of the county which board or discharge passengers; (6) Two hundred yards from an existing licensed arcade or amusement game room, regardless of jurisdiction; (b) For the purposes of this section, distances shall be measured in a straight line from the nearest property boundary line of the location of the proposed amusement game room establishment for which the license is sought, or an existing amusement game room, to the nearest property boundary line of those uses referenced in subsection 18-160(a) above. For school bus stops, such measurement shall be made to the approximate location of the point of discharge. (c) The measurement of such distances shall be confirmed by the McDuffie County Planning Commission staff using the geographical information system (GIS) of McDuffie County. Should a question arise as to the accuracy or authenticity of such measurement, resolution shall be obtained by the confirmation of same by a state certified land surveyor. The expense for the services of such land surveyor shall be borne by the applicant. (d) An amusement game room which is operated pursuant to a license issued by the county prior to the adoption of this article shall not be denied, and shall continue operation under such existing license, nor deny any renewal of such license, nor shall any new operator of such amusement game room be denied a new license based upon the measurements set forth in this section. Upon cessation of the operation of the amusement game room pursuant to such license, such exemption shall expire. (e) If the distance requirements as set forth are met at the time of the issuance of the license, the subsequent establishment of a property use referenced in subsection 18-160(a) shall not prevent the continued operation of the amusement game room pursuant to the license or the renewal of the license to any subsequent operator of such amusement game room as long as the business operation of the amusement game room or establishment does not cease. (f) The board of commissioners may waive the distance requirements of this section as they apply to a county park or playground. (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 10) Sec. 18-161. - Number of bona fide coin-operated amusement game machines. No license shall be issued for any amusement game room having more than six class B amusement game machines as referenced in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70(a)(4) which provide for noncash redemption as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(c) or (d). In addition to the six class B amusement game machines, no more than four class A amusement game machines, as referenced in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70(a)(3), which provide for noncash redemption as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(c) or (d), may be permitted. The total number of amusement game machines per location shall not exceed ten amusement game machines. The substitution of class A amusement game machines for class B game machines may be permitted upon prior approval of the designee. (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 11) Sec. 18-162. - Gross receipts from bona fide coin-operated amusement machines and from business. (a) Every owner or operator of an amusement game room shall keep records available for inspection by the county which shall set out annual gross receipts for class B amusement game machines, separately from other products and services sold at the location. (b) Any location owner or operator subject to O.C.G.A. § 50-27-84(b)(1) may be required, upon prior notice by the county, to provide a monthly report to the county which shall indicate the monthly gross receipts for each business location within the county. Such report shall be due by the twentieth day of each month for the previous month in which the sales have taken place. In addition, each owner or operator must allow the local government an annual audit of the reports from the owner or operator to the [Georgia] Lottery Corporation. (c) No location owner or operator may derive more than 50 percent of such location's monthly gross retail receipts for any location in which the class B machines are located. Any location owner or operator found in violation of such provision may be fined and may have his or her amusement game room license suspended or revoked as allow[ed] in this article. Compliance with this section requires both the availability of records for inspection and compliance with the 50 percent of gross retail receipts requirement. Any violations of this provision may be reported to the Georgia Lottery Corporation. (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 12) Sec. 18-163. - Notice requirements. (a) Every amusement game room shall post a conspicuous sign with the following or substantially similar language: GEORGIA LAW PROHIBITS GIVING OR RECEIPT OF ANY MONEY FOR WINNING A GAME OR GAMES ON AN AMUSEMENT GAME MACHINE; GIVING OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR FREE REPLAYS WON ON AN AMUSEMENT GAME MACHINE; GIVING OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR ANY MERCHANDISE, PRIZE, TOY, GIFT CERTIFICATE, OR NOVELTY WON ON ANY AMUSEMENT GAME MACHINE; OR AWARDING ANY MERCHANDISE, PRIZE, TOY, GIFT CERTIFICATE, OR NOVELTY OF A VALUE EXCEEDING $5.00 FOR A SINGLE PLAY OF AN AMUSEMENT GAME MACHINE. (b) Every amusement game room sign shall be a minimum of 18 inches in height and 30 inches in width with lettering in bold type not less than two inches in height. (c) Every owner or operator shall post the amusement game room license conspicuously and permanently. (d) The owner or operator of each amusement game room shall inform every employee of the acts and omissions prohibited by O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35 and this article, and of the penalties for violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35 and this article. (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 13) Sec. 18-164. - Compliance with O.C.G.A. provision relating to master licenses, location licenses, and stickers for individual machines. Bona fide coin-operated amusement machines may be used in an amusement game room within the county only if the machines are owned by a person who holds a valid master license in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 50-27-71, and each machine offered to the public for play has a valid permit sticker in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 50-27-78. In addition, the business owner where the machines are available for play by the public must pay a location license fee to the [Georgia] Lottery Corporation in order to obtain a valid location license in accordance with O.C.G.A. §§ 50-27-71(a.1) and (b). (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 14) Sec. 18-165. - License suspension and revocation. (a) The county may suspend or revoke an alcohol license of the owner or operator to manufacture, distribute, or sell alcoholic beverages as a penalty for the conviction of the owner or operator for violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e), (f) or (g). (b) The county may suspend or revoke any other license issued by the county to the owner or operator as a penalty for the conviction of the owner or operator for a violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e), (f), or (g). (c) The suspension or revocation of a license under the provision of this article shall be in accordance with the following guidelines: (1) No license which has been issued or which may be issued pursuant to this article shall be suspended or revoked except for due cause and after hearing upon a three-day prior notice to the holder of the license indicating the time, place, and purpose of the hearing and a statement of the charges upon which the hearing shall be held. (2) The term "due cause" for the purposes of this section shall include, but not be limited to: a. Conviction of, or the entering of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere by the licensee or any of his employees or any person holding an interest in the license for any felony, any law, administrative regulation or ordinance involving alcoholic beverages, gambling or narcotics, or tax laws. b. Conviction of, or the entering of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere by the licensee or any of his employees or any person holding an interest in the license for any sex offense when the licensed business is for on-premises consumption. c. Suspension or revocation of any state license required as a condition for the possession, sale, or distribution of alcoholic beverages. d. Material falsification of any fact given in an application for a license issued under this chapter or bearing upon the licensee's qualification therefore. Any act which may be construed as a subterfuge in an effort to circumvent any of the qualifications for a license under this chapter shall be deemed a violation of the requirement attempted to be circumvented. e. Failure to meet or maintain any standard prescribed by this article as a condition or qualification for holding a license. f. Any other factor known to, or discovered by the county whereby it is objectively shown that the licensee, any of the licensee's employees or any person holding an interest in a license, has engaged in conduct at or involving the licensed location or has permitted conduct at the licensed location that constitutes a violation of federal or state law, local ordinance, or administrative regulations involving alcoholic beverages, gambling or narcotics for all alcohol licensed businesses and including any sex offense under state law or local ordinances with respect to businesses licensed for on-premises consumption. With respect to this section, it shall be reputably presumed that the violation was committed with the knowledge or consent of the licensee; provided, however, that such presumption may be rebutted only by evidence which precludes every other reasonable hypothesis save that such licensee did not know, assist, or aid in such occurrence, or in the exercise of full diligence that such licensee could not have discovered or prevented such activity. (3) Notice of suspension or revocation proceedings shall be served on the person named as licensee on the amusement game room license application. Notice shall be in writing and may be served in person, or by first-class mail. If by mail, the notice shall be addressed to the licensee at its address as provided by the licensee to the county. The burden shall be on the licensee to provide notice, in writing, or any change of address for the service of notice and process. In the case of service by mail of any notice required by this chapter, the service is complete at the time of deposit with the United States Postal Service. (4) Hearing shall be held before the board of commissioners and conducted according to normal hearing procedures. The code enforcement officer or other designated personnel shall present the county's case and bear the burden of proving by a preponderance of the evidence that due cause exists to suspend or revoke the amusement game room license. At the hearing the licensee shall have the right to represent itself or be represented by counsel. If represented by council the board of commissioners may proceed with the hearing or may delay the hearing until such time as council for the county is present. The licensee may cross-examine all witnesses offered by the county, and may call witnesses and present evidence on its own behalf. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply to hearings under this section although the board shall have the right to exclude evidence bearing on the lack of reliability. All testimony shall be offered under oath or affirmation. (5) The board shall make its final determination not later than the date of its next regularly scheduled board meeting upon the completion of the hearing. The decision shall be placed in writing and contain the board's finding of fact and any decision as to sanction, if any. Such sanction may include one or more of the following; revocation of the license, suspension of the license for no more than 12 months, imposition of a probationary period not to exceed 12 months, and/or a civil monetary penalty not to exceed $1,000.00. Progressive sanctions, depending on the severity of the violation are encouraged but not required. Where the remaining term of the license is less than 12 months, imposition of the suspension or probation for a period in excess of the term of the existing license shall be applied to any renewal license. A subsequent violation within a probationary period shall be cause for revocation and/or denial of a license renewal. A total of three separate and unrelated violations within 24 months, whether or not within a probationary period, shall be grounds for permanent revocation. (6) The board's decision shall be personally served or mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the licensee, his/her attorney if attorney was present at the hearing, and a copy to the county's attorney if present at the hearing. The decision of the board shall constitute final action by the county, subject to review upon petition for certiorari to the Superior Court of McDuffie County. (7) Upon receipt of notice of adverse action against the licensee under this section, the licensee may waive its right to a hearing and stipulate his/her preference to defer to a board sanction as recommended by the code enforcement officer. Any stipulation to defer to board sanction shall be in writing, signed by the licensee, and non-appealable. (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 15) Sec. 18-166. - Criminal penalties for violations by owners or operators of amusement game rooms. (a) Penalties for violation of the provisions of this article by an owner or operator of an amusement game room, after conviction in the Magistrate Court of McDuffie County, or other court of competent jurisdiction are as follows: (1) First offense: Fine not to exceed $500.00 for each violation. (2) Second offense: Fine not to exceed $750.00 for each violation, suspension of the owner or operator's amusement game room license for not more than three months, or both. (3) Third offense: Fine not to exceed $1,000.00 for each violation, suspension or permanent revocation of the owner's or operator's amusement game room license or suspension of other permits and licenses granted by the county for not more than six months, or any combination thereof. (b) The fines listed in the penalties for violation of this article may be imposed by the Judge of the Magistrate Court of McDuffie County, or the judge of any other court of competent jurisdiction. Suspension of revocation of the owner's or operator's amusement game room license, and suspension of other permits and licenses granted by the county may be imposed by the board of commissioners after a public hearing as set forth in section 18-165 of this article. (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 16) Sec. 18-167. - Penalties for violations by those who play bona fide coin-operated machines in violation of law or ordinance. The Magistrate Court of McDuffie County, or any other court of competent jurisdiction is authorized to impose the following penalties on any person convicted of receiving money as a reward for the successful play or winning on any bona fide coin-operated amusement machine from any person owning, possessing, controlling or overseeing such bona fide coin-operated amusement machine or any person employed by or acting on behalf of a person owning, possessing, controlling or overseeing a bona fide coin-operated amusement machine: (1) First offense: Fine not to exceed $250.00 for each violation. (2) Second and subsequent offense: Fine not to exceed $500.00 for each violation. (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 17) Sec. 18-168. - Applicability of state penalties. In addition to the local penalties as referenced in sections 18-166 and 18-167 above for the violation of the provisions of this article, those found to be in violation the state provisions governing bona fide coin-operated amusement machines shall in addition be subject to the penalties levied by the state as referenced in O.C.G.A. §§ 16-12-35(a) through (k). (Ord. of 2-5-14, § 18) Sec. 18-169. - Operating regulations. (a) Devices to be kept in plain view; gambling devices prohibited.
